We had roast hearts of lettuce with a home made pistachio mayonaisse, creamy garlic soup garnished with fresh peache slices, and a delicious lamb stew. The star dish was the fried eggplant “chips” drizzled with honey with a melted cheese for dipping - just orgasmic. Best dish we have tried in madrid so far. My advice? Ditch the crowded madrid establishments you find in the guide books and head here instead :-)

Everything on the menu looked really interesting - traditional tapas with a modern twist - so we ordered several dishes to share and the menu del dia, which was great value. Everything was full of flavour and very reasonably priced. The staff were very friendly and quick to offer additional dishes on the menu del dia to accommodate the vegetarians in our party. If you like good food and trying new dishes then Gato Gato is definitely worth a visit!

title_review: Personal touches for both food and service
review_preview: Came in for a brunch/lunch and left very satisfied. The place itself is bright and welcoming and this is reflected in the staff's service also. We ordered one chicken, mayo and avocado arepas (needed to Google image it) and one Mexican meal consisting of a...
review_full: Came in for a brunch/lunch and left very satisfied.  The place itself is bright and welcoming and this is reflected in the staff's service also.  We ordered one chicken, mayo and avocado arepas (needed to Google image it) and one Mexican meal consisting of a fried egg, black beans, rice and pulled pork. Wow. Both were utterly delicious!  Another group walked in after us and were treated with some very personal service when they couldn't find exactly what they wanted on the menu. The cook/waiter/owner (seemed to do it all well!) offered to throw together a personal salad for them using ingredients they had despite it not being listed on the menu. He offered suggestions on other food and drinks to have also and did it all in very good English.  This was a perfect find - check it out.

review_preview: We saw Cacao on Trio Advisor and had it on our list as possibilities.  After a morning visit to Prado, we decided to find the restaurant on foot.  Put the address in Google Maps and there we were.  Such a quaint neighborhood --added bonus we...
review_full: We saw Cacao on Trio Advisor and had it on our list as possibilities. After a morning visit to Prado, we decided to find the restaurant on foot. Put the address in Google Maps and there we were. Such a quaint neighborhood --added bonus we would have missed! The service was excellent! We meet both owners and they were so patient describing all the entrees. There were 4 of us and all ordered the same thing as the entree. Pork Tenderloin. I think it sounded so wonderful no one was willing to share. It did not disappoint. So tender and delicious. The potato appetizer and the homemade bread were just as equally delish! To top it off, we were given complimentary homemade coffee aperitif and candies. So wonderful. The 4 of us agreed, this was the best meal had on the 9 day trip to Madrid, Valencia and Barcelona. You will not be disappointed.

title_review: We'll never be back here - staff and service were just awful
review_preview: We booked this restaurant based on the ratings on trip advisor.  It appears to be a take on 'Brew Dog' but falls waaaaay short of the mark.  We were a family of four, and despite booking a table we had to wait, we were ignored...
review_full: We booked this restaurant based on the ratings on trip advisor. It appears to be a take on 'Brew Dog' but falls waaaaay short of the mark. We were a family of four, and despite booking a table we had to wait, we were ignored for a good 10 minutes after checking in when we arrived. Whilst standing waiting we were watching the tv which was on the wall in the bar, goodness knows what channel was on but we were subjected to what I can only describe as a scantily clad 'big daddy' looky likey wearing nothing but a thong and gyrating towards the camera man, not pleasant to say the least. We were eventually shown to a table downstairs which quite clearly seated two as the staff went to find more chairs for us to squeeze our family of four round. We moved ourselves to an empty table of four to be told we could not have that as it was reserved for others. We were moved back to our original table, which I may add looked directly into the gents toilets, where the door stood open unless there was someone in. We couldn't figure out how 4 pizzas were to fit onto our table so we promptly left. The staff couldn't have been less helpful or friendly and made no effort to secure our custom. We felt that the restaurant was trying to squeeze as much people in as possible without any attention to customers whatsoever. We'll not be back and have already told friends to avoid.

title_review: Good pizza.  Awesome beer selection for Americans.
review_preview: Had some good pizza.  Had 3 pints of beer.  An american-style pale ale, and a imperial IPA.  They had a mix of American and Spanish beers.  The pale ale I had was local, but an American west-coast style.  They were all great.  They have a...
review_full: Had some good pizza. Had 3 pints of beer. An american-style pale ale, and a imperial IPA. They had a mix of American and Spanish beers. The pale ale I had was local, but an American west-coast style. They were all great. They have a big selection on tap, so head in if you are getting tired of the usual lagers elsewhere. When I was there, they had belgians, IPAs, pale ales, sours, stouts. They probably had a couple other styles that I don't recall. You can get some of the local beers by bottle or can to go.

title_review: Good Spanish craft beer in a great location
review_preview: We came across this place by chance as it was very near to the hotel we were staying at.The staff were very friendly and as at a lot craft beer place, passionate about craft beer and very knowledgeable about what they had on tap...
review_full: We came across this place by chance as it was very near to the hotel we were staying at. The staff were very friendly and as at a lot craft beer place, passionate about craft beer and very knowledgeable about what they had on tap and what should follow what (so you know, I don’t drink beer craft or otherwise, but I do visit quite a number of these establishments so I know a good craft beer people when I hear them). They had their own berr and so obviously my husband tried all of them and he said they were lovely. They had 15 beers of differing types and strengths. We visited more than once so quite a number were tried. The first night we were off to a particular restaurant and just stopped for drinks but as the beer was good as was the wine and the pizzas looked and smelled delicious, we stopped for pizza. We had the veggie pizza and the capricciosa without ham. Both pizzas were fantastic, a nice tomato sauce, lovely thin stone baked base and a good amount of toppings. They also have a very nice red wine which I drank - generally if craft beer places have red wine, it’s not the best quality but this was lovely. They also have and vodka and gin for the non beer drinking clientele which not every craft beer place has. They even made me a Tinto de Verano (if you have Fanta Lemoade in full view, you should definitely be prepared to have to make one, go on, you know you want to). The place itself is very nicely decorated, the staff are very friendly and speak very good English, it’s very well located close to Plaza de Santa Ana.

title_review: Fantastic food in the Chueca neighborhood
review_preview: If you are looking for a fancy restaurant in central Madrid, this is not the place. If however you want great Spanish food at reasonable prices with friendly, attentive service you need look no further. We ate here our second night in Madrid based on...
review_full: If you are looking for a fancy restaurant in central Madrid, this is not the place. If however you want great Spanish food at reasonable prices with friendly, attentive service you need look no further. We ate here our second night in Madrid based on great Trip Advisor reviews and what a find it was! Hands down, the best meal while in Madrid. Located in the heart of the Chueca neighborhood, this tiny restaurant looks like nothing special from the outside and you easily might pass it by and not give it a thought if you were walking down the street. Either go early or book a reservation because the restaurant is very small and fills up quickly. Once you are seated and Hugo, the owner, comes to greet you, you are in for a real treat. Hugo lived in the US for a while and speaks perfect English. He is also very personable and takes great pains to explain everything on the menu which is entirely in Spanish, making suggestions along the way.  We had four dishes, all of them excellent. The goat cheese salad is a must. I believe the entire bill for two was less than 50 Euros. Amazing! Be sure to put this on your list whenever you are in Madrid.

review_preview: In the heart of Chueca, this lovely, tiny restaurant was an amazing experience.  More than tapas, but brighter and lighter than a traditional restaurant, it is authentically Spanish while being adventurous at the same time, and really REALLY good, with a flair that speaks of...
review_full: In the heart of Chueca, this lovely, tiny restaurant was an amazing experience. More than tapas, but brighter and lighter than a traditional restaurant, it is authentically Spanish while being adventurous at the same time, and really REALLY good, with a flair that speaks of the El Bulli trained chef. I'd go back in a heartbeat, and if I were in Madrid, I could see that I would become a regular. Service is friendly and enthusiastic (and English speaking), and the food really is very special. The wine list is tiny but what there is is perfectly good (and not expensive). I was there on business, but I'd happily go with my husband on "date night", or with our daughter as a family visit.  It was quite busy, even on a Monday night, so I would suggest reserving if you can.

review_preview: What a fantastic place.  We passed by earlier and it didn't look that special -  we were so wrong!  One of my most memorable dining experiences.  The food is fantastic, but what makes this restaurant so special is the personal service and passion of Hugo....
review_full: What a fantastic place. We passed by earlier and it didn't look that special - we were so wrong! One of my most memorable dining experiences. The food is fantastic, but what makes this restaurant so special is the personal service and passion of Hugo. He eloquently describes each course in extreme detail. He clearly loves the business of food and is so knowledgeable. When I commented that the mussels were big and plumb, he explained what they ate, where they came from, etc. A few of our favorites were the tuna tartar with plantain chips, the mussels, the pork, the warm goat cheese and the chocolate desert with shaved coconut that is frozen. The Trip Advisor reviews are all accurate. And you can call ahead to make a reservation later in the afternoon. If you are in Madrid, you must come here for a meal.

review_preview: We came across this by chance and so pleased we did! The complementary meatball tapas with our drinks and the white wine recommended by Laura was excellent. We then decided to have the menu of the day, choosing both choices from the menu for each...
review_full: We came across this by chance and so pleased we did!  The complementary meatball tapas with our drinks and the white wine recommended by Laura was excellent.  We then decided to have the menu of the day, choosing both choices from the menu for each of the courses so we could taste everything!  Every dish was made from scratch; light, fresh and full of flavour. We also were given an additional tapas at the table-Francisco's own croquette which were delicious! Great value at 11.50 euros each, including a drink -house white in our case, which was also very good-and 3 courses Laura and Francisco were warm and friendly hosts and their passion for food and great service shone through in their foods and we look forward to the next time we visit Madrid.  This will be our restaurant of choice- if we can get in because once the message gets around, we reckon we will struggle to book a table. Thanks again for the best food memory of Madrid

The dishes were arriving at different times, which I assume is ok for tapas, however, it was unusual for us to have potatoes with nothing to it and 20 minutes later have tuna served with no sides to it. Anyway, the food is enjoyable and sangria was lovely, albeit we had to remind staff about our drinks. All in all, it was a pleasant enough dining experience but we probably won't be coming back.

title_review: Worth it for the Sangria alone

One of my friends is a very fussy eater and drinker and usually can't stand wine but even she loved it. The food was also absolutely delicious too, tapas being perfect for you to customise to your hunger levels, and our waiter was extremely friendly and helpful at explaining foods we weren't familiar with.

title_review: BEST we have had in ALL of Spain
review_preview: Barcelona, Granada, Sevilla, Cordoba, Toledo, Madrid - THE best restaurant we ate at on every level was Cacao Restobar.  Doesn't look like much at first, but they have more seating in a more comfortable area in the back.  Their kitchen is small, but all that...
review_full: Barcelona, Granada, Sevilla, Cordoba, Toledo, Madrid - THE best restaurant we ate at on every level was Cacao Restobar. Doesn't look like much at first, but they have more seating in a more comfortable area in the back. Their kitchen is small, but all that means is your food is going to get the attention it deserves, though it may take a little while to get to you. They make sangria fresh, so you can get it without sugar. They brought a little appetizer to try - fried arepas cakes. They were declicious!! Sour cream sauce and an avocado sauce, OMG that was a great sign to a great meal coming. Four or five options for vegetarians, the arepas domino (black beans) was super good. The pork tenderloins with potatoes, carmelized onions and a goat cheese sauce, was outstanding. Got the half portion and it made me full. Less than 9 Euros for the 1/2 pork dish, 6 Euros for the arepas domino, and 5 Euros for the glass of Sangria (served in what must have been a 16 oz mug. Bill came to less than 19 Euros. More than the price, and the flavor of the food, the service was great. One guy, Carlos, who speaks English explained the dishes and the vegetarian options. Outstanding service, flavor, and prices - the trifecta in dining out! ADD this to your list, this is a MUST try. It was the best we had in all of Spain

review_preview: After a week of pintxos and tapas, my husband and I had gotten so used to ordering many dishes or a large portion if we wanted to each have a bite. Well, dishes here are delicious and the largest we have had in 8 days...
review_full: After a week of pintxos and tapas, my husband and I had gotten so used to ordering many dishes or a large portion if we wanted to each have a bite. Well, dishes here are delicious and the largest we have had in 8 days in Spain.  (In San Sebastián, 5E gets you one bite of food. Here, 8E got us four separate corn pancake sandwiches.) We were full after that appetizer and then our huge main dishes arrived.  Servers are friendly and accommodating. We were so grateful they were willing to wrap up our leftovers as we hate wasting artfully prepared food (especially when it involves an animal giving its life for our dinner) and because we know to-go bags aren't a normal thing here. We preferred the cava sangria over the white wine sangria, but both were beautifully presented.  The restaurant looks tiny from the road, but has a large back room. We chose the front area as there was a fun vibe and music playing. If it looks full from the road, it's worth going in to ask if there's a table in the other room.

title_review: Pleasant surprise on a quiet street!
review_preview: We decided to go to Cacao since it was close to our hotel and it had received excellent reviews on tripadvisor. The restaurant was surprisingly good! The restaurant is Venezuelan with a Madrid flair.  The owners are from Venezuela and all the staff speaks English....
review_full: We decided to go to Cacao since it was close to our hotel and it had received excellent reviews on tripadvisor. The restaurant was surprisingly good! The restaurant is Venezuelan with a Madrid flair. The owners are from Venezuela and all the staff speaks English. Everyone was very friendly and helpful. We started with their arepas platter and the mediterranean salad. Both were very good. We then had the grilled calamari, fajitas, mushroom risotto, and the pulled pork with plantains. The food was seasoned very well, brought hot to the table, and tasted very fresh. The mushroom risotto was surprisingly delicious! It was cooked in an amazing mushroom broth and not too creamy! We would highly recommend. It's a nice break from the traditional Madrid restaurants.

The food arrived as and when it was ready and the final dish to arrive was the beef tacos (2 in a portion) these were so tasty and a great end to the meal. The meal cost €44 for 2 beers, 1 cocktail, 1 coke and the 5 dishes which we thought was great value for money. We would’ve loved desserts but were too full to even look at the menu. I would suggest trying to book in advance as there was a constant stream of people arriving, we booked online and noticed the server was often busy and couldn’t answer the phone so it’s best to drop by or book online if possible.

review_preview: Firstly, let me congratulate Hugo (who speaks very good English), Marcelo and Gabi for creating a wonderful ambiance and offering exceptional service of this not-your-typical tapas taberna!  Also, "brava" to the unknown chef tucked away in the kitchen. Reservations are highly recommended since the restaurant...
review_full: Firstly, let me congratulate Hugo (who speaks very good English), Marcelo and Gabi for creating a wonderful ambiance and offering exceptional service of this not-your-typical tapas taberna! Also, "brava" to the unknown chef tucked away in the kitchen. Reservations are highly recommended since the restaurant is small, and always packed with vibrant and lively diners. What did we eat? Well, the salmorejo was outstanding, the warm goat cheese with crisped honey was divine, the veal cooked to perfection, and the tuna tartare was superb. As far as dessert, you must have the mojito sorbet with white rum drizzled over and served in a martini glass. Beautiful presentation of all the foods...the best meal I've had in Madrid, hands down!

title_review: Our favorite Madrid experience but be sure to reserve or get there early
review_preview: Tried to get in one night about 9:45 and no luck (the place is pretty small -- about a dozen tables), so we went back the next night about 9 and were successful. They were packed within a half hour. Everyone seemed to be having...
review_full: Tried to get in one night about 9:45 and no luck (the place is pretty small -- about a dozen tables), so we went back the next night about 9 and were successful. They were packed within a half hour. Everyone seemed to be having a grand time sampling the dishes -- the energy was palpable. It's not fancy, but don't let that deter you. We were made to feel extremely welcome and the owner went over every dish on the menu with us. We settled on the gazpacho, the foie salad with mango, Mussels Tikka Masala (so off-the-wall, we had to try it), the rabbit, and the pork loin -- all excellent and excitingly flavored. For dessert: a chocolaty mousse and a sensational peach sorbet with a red wine reduction. Prices were very reasonable. We hated to call it a night. We were so impressed, we returned on our last night in Madrid -- we re-ordered some of the same dishes, but also enjoyed the tuna tartare, croquettes and spareribs. No less wonderful than the first night. This place is well-regarded by locals and appears quite humble from the outside (it's in the Chueca area) . However, venture in and you're in for a wonderful night. I wish them much continued success.

title_review: This completed our Spain trip on a high note!
review_preview: It was our last night in Spain and I chanced upon the reviews of Taberna Gastromaquia on Tripadvisor. We were staying at Hotel Regina which was about 10 minutes walk from the restaurant. Armed with google maps on my phone, we set out to find...
review_full: It was our last night in Spain and I chanced upon the reviews of Taberna Gastromaquia on Tripadvisor. We were staying at Hotel Regina which was about 10 minutes walk from the restaurant. Armed with google maps on my phone, we set out to find the place. We went early (at about 9:15pm) as we didn't have reservation.  The restaurant is not very big but the layout & service is amazing. We were led to a table right away and one of the staff came to explain the entire menu to us in English (the menu is in Spanish). I am a vegetarian but my husband is not. The maitre d serving us suggested some great dishes and ensured we had ordered enough.  We had the pan seared goats cheese, mushroom croquettes, guacamole with the plantain chips and pork skewers. The food was simply excellent. We wanted to try the grilled asparagus (it looked so nice) but we were stuffed. The maitre d recommned the mojito sorbet and insisted we tried it. And we are so glad we did! This was one of the best sorbets I have had - refreshing and sweet! Given the quality and great service, this place is great value for money. This will be on top of my must-do list if we ever visit Madrid again.

review_preview: My boyfriend and I are passionate foodies and have had some hits and some misses in Madrid. On our last night we wanted a definite hit so chose to go with a tripadvisor review and were not disappointed!Hero dishes included goat cheese in a...
review_full: My boyfriend and I are passionate foodies and have had some hits and some misses in Madrid.  On our last night we wanted a definite hit so chose to go with a tripadvisor review and were not disappointed! Hero dishes included goat cheese in a basil honey sauce (I am goat cheese obsessed and this dish was one of the best I have ever had)! Also a winner was rabbit and I really dislike rabbit, to the extent I really tried to get my boyfriend to order something else.... But I think I might be converted!!  Service was fantastic... Knowledgeable and friendly. Only minus was the place did need a little music of something to liven the place up... Although the place was quite full so the chat made up for it. I recommend booking, as we hadn't and were very lucky to get a table ( we waited outside until they opened at 8.30pm, which seems crazy late to us Aussie/Pommes), but they were turning away tables whilst we were inside. The maitre d spoke brilliant English so calling and booking would be easy enough. Also wine was a really reasonable price!  Try this place, really great tapas and honestly brilliant value for money-we paid the same as a dinner in touristy crappy places, yet this place was a million times more refined and deliciois! Enjoy!

review_preview: My wife found this just searching the area near where we had a HomeAway Apt. At his was our third and final night in Madrid, following a day we walk for over 6.5 miles... PERFECT for our last night .. Walked in front, began selecting...
review_full: My wife found this just searching the area near where we had a HomeAway Apt. At his was our third and final night in Madrid, following a day we walk for over 6.5 miles... PERFECT for our last night ..  Walked in front, began selecting a seat in the bar area but we're very politely asked if we were there for more than drinks, which we were.. We were escorted to the dining area which was well in the back but extremely nice... Tiny with room for maybe 20 total.  Our wait person (we learned later was Carlos) was the nicest you could ask for (although it turned out, everyone was that way)... After an appropriate amount of time (drinks already in hand) we began to place our order.. My Prawns in garlic was to be a small dish (tapas possibly) and Liz began to order two large arapas... Carlos was a quick to say that she should try the "other" arapas which seemed in the menu to be small but a sampling of 4... It did cost less...  When delivered my prawns and garlic were 4 full prawns and 4 shrimp with ton of olive oil and tons of garlic.. If your mouth isn't watering you may want to order something else. But if it is, this will be better than I have described.. The selection of 4 arapas for Liz proved to be more than she could have handled for a meal... I ate the two meat filled (she's a vegetarian) and she had bread soaked in my olive oil and garlic.. We were both stuffed... One more round of drinks and, we asked for a check which was delivered with two shots of homemade Bailey's... Best ever and we bought a tiny bottle to take with us..  Okay, the good stuff.. Waitstaff.. Just ask for Carlos... There are 4 that work there.. We met two of them and there are no better servers anywhere.. Want to talk to the owner? Ask for Eddie... Eddie Dad, Momma, nephew, son and one other are all involved in the business... And we met all of them.. If I had this place near my home, I likely would be there more than home.. Just a fantastic place on a tiny street in Madrid Spain!

review_preview: We stumbled upon this place as we were looking for a lunch spot not too far from the Westin Palace, but not near all the craziness.  Trip Advisor gave us the idea for this one as we looked for a highly rated spot near where...
review_full: We stumbled upon this place as we were looking for a lunch spot not too far from the Westin Palace, but not near all the craziness. Trip Advisor gave us the idea for this one as we looked for a highly rated spot near where we were as we walked the Madrid streets. There is a bar area with a few tables and an area in the back with more tables. We are in the restaurant area.  The service here was wonderful and their English is good. They helped with the menu and they also allowed some modifications to get exactly what we wanted. We started with nachos with chicken and it was tasty. The small portion was plenty to share for 2-3 as an app.  We went with the chicken fajitas, the salmon with potatoes and veggies (be sure to specify how well you want the salmon cooked), and the Caesar salad. All were very good and enjoyed by all. We were extremely pleased with the nuanced flavors and beautiful presentations of the food.  The latte's to finish were perfect to finish a terrific lunch. This should go on your list as a great lunch spot and the prices were moderate and good value for the quality of the food.

review_preview: We have been to Brew Wild a few times and only just now writing an overdue review. It is in a great central location, so it's a fun and convenient to stop in for beers if you are in the area, or grabbing a pizza...
review_full: We have been to Brew Wild a few times and only just now writing an overdue review. It is in a great central location, so it's a fun and convenient to stop in for beers if you are in the area, or grabbing a pizza if it is meal time. The pizzas are decent, but being candid: this isn't an authentic wood fired/Neapolitan place - so set expectations accordingly. The Vulcano and Diavolo are strong choices, and there are a few other good options we have sampled.  The star here is the rotating taps of draft beers. Brew Wild has 15 taps, usual with a few IPAs of varying hoppiness, a pale ale or two, a session IPAs, doubles, ambers, pilsners, and an iambic or stout mixed in. They switch it up fairly frequently. They offer a good choice of bottled treats as well, but in my opinion the taps reign supreme. Being accustomed to US east coast craft breweries and a lot of beer diversity and availability of high quality draft beer, Brew Wild is a rare jewel in Madrid. I truly hope they get more competition in the central Madrid area - but as of now they are one of the few tap dominated establishments. You can find many other places with a decent bottle selection, or even the odd IPA on draft, but not with this much selection. Cheers to the staff, who routinely seem to know the beers and are super friendly. We have always had samples offered and great recommendations made based on our tastes and beer moods. Prices are ok to slightly high, but considering they really have little competition it is understood.

title_review: Excellent Beer Bar and Pizza spot; Especially if you're an American.
review_preview: My wife and I just went here tonight. We are "beer snobs" from New York, and this place did not disappoint. The service was friendly and prompt, the beers were diverse and excellently served, and the pizza was tasty and enjoyable. For any Americans who...
review_full: My wife and I just went here tonight. We are "beer snobs" from New York, and this place did not disappoint. The service was friendly and prompt, the beers were diverse and excellently served, and the pizza was tasty and enjoyable. For any Americans who feel a little alienated by the local populace, I found this place very inviting. There were a lot of fellow US'ers there and the staff seemed genuinely interested in the different microbrews we had been to in the NY area. Staff speaks English well and they are very welcoming. If you like beer, and are feeling a little homesick, I highly recommend this place. My wife wanted to add that the pizza was thin crust, in case that matters to people (it apparently does to her).

review_preview: I don't write a lot of Trip Advisor reviews, but I felt compelled because Gastromaquia - and Hugo - were utterly charming!  We had a perfect "Farewell Madrid" dinner here last week.  Based on earlier reviews, I knew to make a reservation.  I called from...
review_full: I don't write a lot of Trip Advisor reviews, but I felt compelled because Gastromaquia - and Hugo - were utterly charming! We had a perfect "Farewell Madrid" dinner here last week. Based on earlier reviews, I knew to make a reservation. I called from the US and got Hugo (who is the front of the house and dessert guy). He spoke English (a plus!) and was very gracious. We showed up at our allotted time and the place was empty. I thought "uh oh" - but we're just early, gauche Americans and the crowd soon rolled in! There were 4 of us and we split 5 dishes - probably 1 too many. Being a Texan, I was skeptical about trying the guacamole, but I have to say it was one of the best I've had! The Tikka Masala Mussels were also notable. Oh - and the crazy salad with the huge slab of broiled cheese and pesto! Amazing!  The service was great, the food was amazing (definitely on the rich side, but worth it), and we were treated to an extra dessert (some sort of yummy mojito sorbet).  From the looks of the wait in the front, they don't really need my recommendation, but they certainly receive it!

review_preview: In Madrid there are many choices for restaurants.  We headed to Taberna Gastromaquia by taxi; it is a very small restaurant in a less touristy part of town.  Our friend and researcher had found it on the internet and thought it would be a "foody"...
review_full: In Madrid there are many choices for restaurants. We headed to Taberna Gastromaquia by taxi; it is a very small restaurant in a less touristy part of town. Our friend and researcher had found it on the internet and thought it would be a "foody" experience - which it was. Four of us ordered food and shared it. We had the guacamole, which was served with crispy plantain slices, tuna tartare, which was delicious but leaned heavily toward mustard, might not order it next time, a goat cheese salad which was everyone's favorite, tiki marsala mussels which was a very close second favorite, the octopus with potato foam which tasted a lot like gourmet macaroni and cheese with octopus in every best sense of the word, and we may have ordered more because it felt like the dishes kept coming at a wonderfully relaxing rate. With wine and dessert it was a filling but delicious meal. Maybe the best part was being served by the friendly and happy Hugo. It was a wonderful evening. Only about 24 seats so make a reservation FOR SURE, and early - or you will not get in.

review_preview: We tried this restaurant based on fellow Tripadvisors' recommendations.  We were a little skeptical when we pulled up to the front of the restaurant.  Could this be the 26th best restaurant in Madrid?  Maybe we had the wrong address?  We were waved in by the...
review_full: We tried this restaurant based on fellow Tripadvisors' recommendations. We were a little skeptical when we pulled up to the front of the restaurant. Could this be the 26th best restaurant in Madrid? Maybe we had the wrong address? We were waved in by the friendly dessert chef/server (Hugo?). He and his cooking partner worked at the former El Bulli, and he had lived and worked in the U.S. He enthusiastically walked us through each item on the Spanish-only menu, answering our many questions. The highlight for us was the venison carpaccio appetizer with macadamia nuts, sprouts and Manchego cheese. Fantastic flavor combination. It was difficult not to want to try everything on the menu. There are only about 20 tables in the restaurant. Give it a try -- you will have a great tasting time.

review_preview: I was incredibly lucky to stumble upon this restaurant on TA.  My girlfriend and I both love food and when I narrowed the places to eat in Madrid to the neighborhood we were staying in, this popped up as the top option.  The name stood...
review_full: I was incredibly lucky to stumble upon this restaurant on TA. My girlfriend and I both love food and when I narrowed the places to eat in Madrid to the neighborhood we were staying in, this popped up as the top option. The name stood out, and the glowing reviews solidified our choice of dinner for one of our only two nights in Madrid. We were greeted very warmly by the staff and immediately felt right at home in this relatively small, and simply decorated restaurant. Hugo, one of the owners came out and chatted with us a bit. He spoke perfect English and translated the whole menu from Spanish and gave us detailed descriptions of the food. There are a number of different dishes on the menu designed to be shared; we picked a couple that sounded perfect. We had the Foie Gras, the Goat Cheese, the Tikka Masala Mussels, the Octopus with Potato Foam, and the Pork Skewers. For dessert we had the Chocolate Foam and the Mojito Sorbet. It was a lot of food, but we left happily stuffed. Every dish was incredibly well prepared and each was equally as good as the last. Presentation was incredible! I have had the opportunity through work and life to eat at a number of very good and well known restaurants. This was hands down among the best meals I have ever had! Hugo had a passion for all of the food and was very concerned with our dining experience and whether we enjoyed each dish. But, more importantly, when we left and thanked him, he made sure to point out that he was just a part of the experience and that his partner, cooking in the kitchen, as well as his staff, were also a big part of the evening. I cannot say enough good things about this place. The only downside is that we had to fly home the next day and could not enjoy it again. The price for the evening (with a bottle of wine) was incredibly reasonable for a multi course menu. It's by no means a cheap place to eat, but for what we received it was a steal! When I come back to Madrid this will be the first place I come to eat. I highly recommend giving this place shot, you will not be disappointed.

review_preview: We visited last week, having read the reviews on TA - and just loved it! As others have said, Hugo the owner speaks perfect english and is totally passionate about his food and restaurant. He explained the entire menu, and then left us to choose,...
review_full: We visited last week, having read the reviews on TA - and just loved it! As others have said, Hugo the owner speaks perfect english and is totally passionate about his food and restaurant. He explained the entire menu, and then left us to choose, saying that he would guide us with the amount to order. The food is for sharing, and just appears at intervals, so we started with the foie gras - amazing! And judged perfectly - just the right amount of melba toast to go with it. As we were finishing that the goat’s cheese appeared - fantastic! It had a crispy top, and coated in a basil oil and honey dressing - just delicious. Well flavoured, but perfectly balanced. Having read reviews of the orange salad we chose that - very lovely, but slightly too rich after our first 2 courses - maybe better suited to follow something like the guacamole. We also tried the tikka mussels - huge mussels, beautifully presented, fabulous sauce. We then had pork skewers, advised by Hugo to order just 1 each - he was spot on. We shared 2 desserts - strawberry and cola, very odd when you just tasted the cola reduction - then stunning when you added in the strawberry mix! Also the mango soup with yogurt ice cream. This is very clever cooking, in an unfussy setting. The tables are close together, so don't go for a romantic evening or if you want lots of space around you. The atmosphere was fun and buzzy, the other staff lovely and friendly and smiling at our attempts to communicate. Great place, fantastic food, really worth visiting - it's just a few mins walk off Gran Via. My best eating experience in Madrid by far.

title_review: A menu you won't find anywhere else, not to be missed!
review_preview: When you walk in you're likely to find Hugo welcoming you from the bar.  After a few minutes with him you'd probably stay if he were serving cheese whiz on ritz crackers.  Instead, the culinary creations you're about to be presented with are likely to...
review_full: When you walk in you're likely to find Hugo welcoming you from the bar. After a few minutes with him you'd probably stay if he were serving cheese whiz on ritz crackers. Instead, the culinary creations you're about to be presented with are likely to be your tastebud's highlight of your time in Madrid. We arrived with no reservation, but were told "no problem" which was only because of the early hour we arrived. Within 30 minutes there wasn't a seat left open in the house. Hugo explained every item on the menu in English to us while simultaneously seeming to direct the effort of every employee in the restaurant and keeping tabs on the happiness of all his customers. We started with the guacamole which was butter smooth, rich with flavor, and made just a bit more interesting by the plantain chips. We also got the tiki muscles and pork skewers, both of which would have been the stand alone star in most restaurants, but in my opinion best dish of the meal was the orange salad. Sure, I could try to describe it, but have you ever tried to describe a sunset or the feeling of a warm shower after a long day? The only way to know it is to experience it! We also finished the meal with the Mojito sorbet and chocolate before asking for a reservation to come back and eat there once more before leaving Madrid. Our second meal there was as good as the first.

title_review: Fabulous, our best meal in Madrid!!
review_preview: We had a reservation here on our first night in Madrid. Needless to say, it was our best meal of our 5 days here. Menu was in Spanish, but the owner, Hugo could not have been nice. He translated the entire menu, talked about his...
review_full: We had a reservation here on our first night in Madrid. Needless to say, it was our best meal of our 5 days here. Menu was in Spanish, but the owner, Hugo could not have been nice. He translated the entire menu, talked about his family, where he is from, others he has worked with, etc. he made recommendations and suggestions of what to order. We took his advice and the food was out of this world. It is a small restaurant and we went relatively early which is unheard of. We had a 9pm reservation and believe it or not, that is early for Madrid. The octopus was fabulous and that is something that we would not normally eat. Prices were reasonable. Hugo even have us his card with his cell phone number and told us to call him if we needed any help around the city. Nicest guy, excellent, reasonable meal. Do not miss!! Located in a quiet, small area in the Chueca section.

review_preview: Not a lot I can add to all of the other excellent reviews - except to say, don't go if you are looking for a sumptuous setting, subdued lighting and lots of personal space.Do go, if you are prepared to be culinarily delighted, are...
review_full: Not a lot I can add to all of the other excellent reviews - except to say, don't go if you are looking for a sumptuous setting, subdued lighting and lots of personal space. Do go, if you are prepared to be culinarily delighted, are happy to chat to your fellow diners (tables are a little squeezed) mostly about how amazing each others' dishes look and taste, are happy to venture a little off the beaten track (our 11 year old's face as we walked through the local area was a picture!) and would like to be charmed, enlightened and deliciously fed by Chef Hugo and his team.   Long after our return from Madrid, we can't recall any of the other places we visited to eat, but this one stays in our memories.

review_full: Due to the size of our party we weren’t able to be seated straight away, but it wasn’t too much hardship to sip sangria in the street while we waited! The tapas was hot, fresh and delicious, with variety to suit every palate. We had cocktails which were refreshing, and complimented the food. Our entire bill came to just under 20 euros a head, which was a bargain considering we hadn’t held back. Some of the dishes were ‘taster’ size so I would suggest clarifying portions if you are worried about over ordering. At the end of the meal the owner gave us discount cards for a local club which was a nice touch.

title_review: Awesome bar with the coolest cave basement! Delicious craft beer and super friendly staff!
review_preview: If I could give more than 5 stars, I would! We spotted this bar while walking around and I am SO happy we stopped in for a beer. We got there right as they opened so one of the owners/partners just hung out and chatted...
review_full: If I could give more than 5 stars, I would!  We spotted this bar while walking around and I am SO happy we stopped in for a beer. We got there right as they opened so one of the owners/partners just hung out and chatted with us for a while while updating the tap list (they also have an awesome bottle collection- check it out!). He was SO nice and knew a ton about the craft beer scene in Spain. He talked to us about different breweries in Madrid and Barcelona and had us sample a couple beers. We have traveled to breweries and craft beer bars all around the world and Brew Wild was one of my all-time favorite experiences.  The beer was all fabulous and the atmosphere of the bar was great. Wonderful music and a neat aesthetic. The basement is super cool- it looks just like a cave! We were really sad the bar was closing early that day because we totally would have come back for pizza and beer in the cave-ey downstairs area. I am going to go back to this bar next time I'm in Madrid!

title_review: Don't miss this place: the best!!
review_preview: We ate dinner here last night and couldn't have been happier. The staff was welcoming and when we ordered, they suggested we have fewer plates and order only 1/2 portions. We ate a chicken and avocado arepa, pork tenderloin, mixed fajitas, and shared ice cream...
review_full: We ate dinner here last night and couldn't have been happier. The staff was welcoming and when we ordered, they suggested we have fewer plates and order only 1/2 portions. We ate a chicken and avocado arepa, pork tenderloin, mixed fajitas, and shared ice cream with dark, rich chocolate sauce. All 1/2 portions were enough for at least two helpings each, with food left over. Delicious!! The food is a combination of Venezuelan and Spanish dishes. The drinks were ridiculously generous and dinner concluded with two free shots of Bailey's, I think. The servers were charming, fluent in English. The place was full of happy people. I'd suggest reservations. Now a favorite place in Madrid and relatively inexpensive with cocktails, beer, water, Coke Zero, and food around 50 Euros total.

review_preview: Don't let the exterior or small, simple interior décor of this place fool you.  The food here is great!  We went on our first night in Madrid and we enjoyed it so much that we went back the next night, too.The part owner/waiter speaks...
review_full: Don't let the exterior or small, simple interior décor of this place fool you. The food here is great! We went on our first night in Madrid and we enjoyed it so much that we went back the next night, too. The part owner/waiter speaks great English and will translate the entire menu for you. The other waiter didn't speak much English, but was very friendly and helpful. All in all, the service was great. They eat late in Spain, so it wasn't a problem for us to get a table when they opened at 8:30 for dinner. The second night we got there a little later (I think at about 9:30) and there was only one free table (thank goodness). We were in Madrid during the week, so I can imagine that it may be harder to get a table on Fri/Sat/Sun nights as they only have table seating for about 20, plus a little bar space (maybe 6 or so). The first night we had their special tuna tartar and my husband enjoyed it so much that he wanted to order it again the second night. I tried patatas bravas in several other restaurants during our time in Barcelona and Madrid and I enjoyed it here the most. The octopus in the cheese sauce topped with a generous sprinkling of paprika was wonderful. I generally don't like squid or octopus because of the chewiness, but this dish was cooked so well that the octopus was not chewy. We also had the ribs, fajitas (which were more like quesadillas in my opinion), mussels, and goat cheese salad. Beware of the ribs -- the portion was big. We had already had the tuna tartar, a small order of the patatas bravas (which comfortably served two), and the octopus before the ribs came out. I wasn't expecting the ribs to be so big, nor did I expect the side of mashed potatoes. Everything we had was yummy, bursting with various flavors that blended so well together.  The price was not bad for the food that you got and I felt like it was a really good value. From my recollection, the dishes range from about 10 to 15 Euros, with the full-sized meals (like the ribs) at about 20 Euros (maybe even less). The small order of the patatas bravas was only 5 Euros though. Note that they do have a bread charge of 1.50 Euros per person, but they just bring the bread to you and don't mention that part. All in all, my husband and I highly recommend this restaurant.

review_preview: Again we trusted trip advisor reviews for a night out in Madrid. Following a quick drink in Mercado San Anton we went to Gastromaquia, which was a 3 minutes walk away in the chueca district., no reservation so lucky to get a table for 2...
review_full: Again we trusted trip advisor reviews for a night out in Madrid. Following a quick drink in Mercado San Anton we went to Gastromaquia, which was a 3 minutes walk away in the chueca district., no reservation so lucky to get a table for 2 as it was busy...always a good sign. The look fof the place makes you think "uh oh" is this a bad choice, and inside the decor and furniture is no frills. BUT...forget that. The welcome, warmth and friendliness of the staff puts you at ease right away. Menus are in spanish and easy to follow, although...important for travellers, the owner speaks perfcet english and loves explaining the menú in detail so you understand it fully. My wife is vegetarian and there were plenty of options. We shared goats cheese balsamic salad with a honey crust...divine! patatas bravas with spicy chill and rich mayo salsas...wow! asparagus with parmesan shavings and more balsamic...yum! marinated pork skewers...again divine! White wine was rueda verdejo, excellent. we didnt need a desert but he insisted on one on the house which was an explosive mojito sorbet...stunning. Bill in total was under 60 €, really good value considering location and quality of food. throughout the owner told us about the business, its evolution, his training - hes a chef too - he has been friends with the chef/partner for 23 years...its a winning combination. We were that impressed that we were going to book for friday, but they close today for summer holidays (normal in Madrid) until 22 August. we will be there then!!! You have to admire places like this, the effort on service and food really makes it a must visit. There are so many options in Madrid, and we have yet to have a bad experience...and if you go here, you wont be disappointed. Really enjoyed the night.

We happen to have gone on the first night of their new location - right next door to the old location. The setting is bright and clean. The atmosphere is vibrant despite it being a small locale. One warning - the restaurant has two seatings - one at 8:30pm and another at 10:30. However, service is incredibly slow - instead of serving all appetizers at once, they seem to arrive every 20 minutes or so. If you don't want to have the bill thrown at you before you've even ordered dessert - I suggest you insist on moving from one plate to another more quickly. I look forward to our next visit to try the other half of the menu!

review_preview: We were almost three weeks in Spain and have eaten in a lot of restaurants. A very few are above average, but this one is perhaps the best we had during this stay.One warning: if you see the appearance of the street and the...
review_full: We were almost three weeks in Spain and have eaten in a lot of restaurants. A very few are above average, but this one is perhaps the best we had during this stay. One warning: if you see the appearance of the street and the building, it will mislead you! But do go in, say that you did/did not reservate and look for a table. The waiters (especially the shorter one) is very very friendly. He speaks over three languages (at least Spanish, Catalan, English and French) and do everything to help you to make your best choice. He also helps you to order enough for your appetite at that moment, but also not to much. Now something about the food. It is tasteful in any ways. No unnecessary fried thing, but cooked as a chef. That's what we like. You can order your dishes per person, but it is more usual to share it with your table partner. The house wine was extremely good for a vino tinto de la casa. And now the smash: order the chocolate mousse as a dessert. Ask the waiter what is in it, be surprised and do order it! You will have an excellent dinner in a restaurant with an atmosphere you would not expect. Perhaps that is the only minus. Maybe they will light the hanging lamps instead of the TL-lamps; that would improve enormously I think. Enjoy.

title_review: Intimate, casual, and friendly food in Chueca.
review_preview: We'd heard about this place from different review sites including Yelp.  It's a very small place with maybe twenty seats maximum.  We got lucky and walked in off the street.  We had to wait for a table but thankfully we were just two people and...
review_full: We'd heard about this place from different review sites including Yelp. It's a very small place with maybe twenty seats maximum. We got lucky and walked in off the street. We had to wait for a table but thankfully we were just two people and hit it just right. Definitely call ahead and make a reservation if you can. Your hotel can do it but they also speak English if you need to do so. If you like thoughtful and inspired food served as it is cooked, then you will like this place! This is not a place for a quick dinner because Spaniards actually enjoy food and dining together. Our meal was well-paced, easy, and fun. The owner took very good care of us and pretty much every table in the restaurant.  I speak decent Spanish but the owner clearly wanted to speak English so he could really explain the menu. I really appreciated that because it was clear how proud he was of his food. His English is excellent. It turns out he lived not far from us in DC a few years back. He was very helpful and really took pains to help us order the right amount of food. He even talked us out of something because he thought we might have too much. He was right! I disagree with other reviewers (on Yelp) who may have found him to be pushy. He was not pushy at all and really took the time to help us and have a nice chat. The prices were very reasonable given the exchange rate between euros and dollars. We had plenty to eat and drink for about 67 euros and we're two guys. Everything was impeccably cooked and plated. My favorites were the pig's ears (try them if they are offering them that night!) the queso de cabra (which is grilled and drizzled in honey) and the secreto iberico (pork brochette) but the rabbit was delicious too. In short, eat here if you want something fun, relaxed, and delicious! Sidenote: they take credit cards and serve wines by the glass (average price was between 2.5 and 3 euros a glass) I can't wait to come back and eat here again!

As others have stated, Hugo immediately came to the rescue by describing each dish and identified which dishes were appropriate for our party. We tried a number of dishes including the guacamole, tuna, goat cheese, asparagus, and the mojito sorbet. Everything was sharable and we enjoyed every dish. The wine was also very reasonable. There are only a few tables in this restaurant so plan ahead - we went on a Tuesday evening but made reservations anyway. I highly recommend this restaurant if you're in Madrid!

title_review: Would prefer tapas without hair during the next visit
review_preview: This restaurant has rave reviews, so as a foodie I decided after a long search to go ahead and give this place a shot. The atmosphere was charming, the servers were kind, the food was decent though not spectacular, and then... the hair. I can...
review_full: This restaurant has rave reviews, so as a foodie I decided after a long search to go ahead and give this place a shot. The atmosphere was charming, the servers were kind, the food was decent though not spectacular, and then... the hair.  I can accept that these things happen, but when a long, black, kinky hair is clearly buried in the middle of my iberico ham croquette, I start to question how it got baked in there, and for how long it's actually been in there... it's not like it fell in on the way to the table. I didn't make much of a fuss, because we did enjoy what we had (again, a 6-7/10) but then we got the calamari which also had a hair, albeit a different length and color, fried into the batter. I think everyone has to draw a line somewhere, and this is where I drew mine. My husband and I couldn't bring ourselves to eat anything further. We had such high hopes, but I must admit, we weren't blown away, with or without hair.  I ended up having a second dinner afterwards elsewhere... so I'm giving this restaurant 2 stars- just as it gave me 2 hairs.

review_full: We visited Gastronomica on Our first night in Madrid and made a reservation to return on Our last night. The service was excellent, Hugo spoke English and had lived in New York for awhile. We tried almost everything on the menu! Patatas bravas with two sauces, artichoke special thinly sliced with the best ever romanesco sauce! Fajatias like we've never seen before! The best skewers, and a mustard tuna tartare.....yum! Great wine! We shared a few desserts the frozen mojito with rum, and an amazing chocolate extravaganza. GASTRONOMICA IS ON a small street and the restaurant is intimate. Great for young and older adults.The prices are reasonable and everything is freshly prepared! We will definitely be back on Our next visit to Madrid.

title_review: Welcoming, bustling atmosphere with good food
review_preview: Do not expect to arrive here early and expect to get in.  They are closed until they are open (is that a Yogism?).  Once you do get in, you will find a narrow seating area.  It will very quickly get crowded and with good reason....
review_full: Do not expect to arrive here early and expect to get in. They are closed until they are open (is that a Yogism?). Once you do get in, you will find a narrow seating area. It will very quickly get crowded and with good reason. The owner will ensure you understand everything on the menu and will try to make sure you are completely satisfied. Food was very good, although not excellent. Prices were not outlandish, but certainly not a bargain. A nice place where you will leave contented.

If you're tired of the same, repetative Madrid tapas menus, come here - it will lift your spirits!

Besides that I told the waiters and they were trying to convince me that it was a T bone steak. They tried to convince me continuously until I told them that I’m a professional chef and I was here in Spain for a chefs seminar with Gordon Blue. I told them that I knew what I ordered and I knew what I received and it was definitely not a T bone steak. At the end they removed the steaks from the fridge for display so that other customers will not be able to see the steak that they order. Everyone needs to be careful what they order and what they receive.

review_preview: This review is actually for the Steakburger Bar on Atocha, but since this is a chain, I expect that the food will be very similar.  Our experience was very disappointing.I love hamburgers.  I´m the kind of guy that when I travel in the US,...
review_full: This review is actually for the Steakburger Bar on Atocha, but since this is a chain, I expect that the food will be very similar. Our experience was very disappointing. I love hamburgers. I´m the kind of guy that when I travel in the US, I will ask people where the best burger joint in town is. So I think I know a good burger, and while these guys market the product right, it was not very good. I admit, I like my meat cooked well, so when it comes back rare, we obviously are getting off to a bad start. And when it comes back the second time only medium, they´ve pretty much lost me. But truly, our burger lacked flavor and was just not appetizing. The fries portion is very small, think McDonalds regular size envelope.  The service was friendly and efficient and the bathrooms were very clean. Its a great location for access to Atocha and other main sights, and they have outdoor seating. We had walked by several of these and I was anxious to give it a try. Been there, done that. I won´t be back. There are just too many better options for burgers in Madrid, in my opinion. Cost for two basic burgers with fries and drinks came to 23 Euros.

review_preview: I’ve been in Madrid for a few days and it’s been pretty hard for me to keep up with the schedules of most restaurants due the the seemingly ever changing business hours. I was hungry walking down the street and noticed Steakburger with open door....
review_full: I’ve been in Madrid for a few days and it’s been pretty hard for me to keep up with the schedules of most restaurants due the the seemingly ever changing business hours. I was hungry walking down the street and noticed Steakburger with open door. I walked in to meet Diego who told me their kitchen was open. He directed me to a bench seat next to a window with a nice breeze and view of the very active Calle de Fuencarral. He took my order of a steakburger (because why not) and made a few recommendations. It was prepared just how I wanted it. Diego was very attentive during my visit. I would defintleh recommend steakburger to anyone with a craving for a good beef, ox or chicken burger.

Later on when my friends and I arrived 3 hours later, they had no note or memory of my booking. They told us we'd have to wait for a table. We waited 15 minutes and asked again, the waiter was very rude and said he was 'looking'. We could see that no one was looking. The waiter then asked another colleague to deal with us, she said she hadn't heard anything and would look. Both staff were very rude and after waiting half an hour we left and went to a restaurant across the street.

review_preview: We visited here for dinner on a Monday around 9:15 PM. We were greeted and seated quickly and the server automatically grabbed English menus for us. He was good at explaining the difference between beef and ox, the two hooved meat options. I ordered the...
review_full: We visited here for dinner on a Monday around 9:15 PM. We were greeted and seated quickly and the server automatically grabbed English menus for us. He was good at explaining the difference between beef and ox, the two hooved meat options. I ordered the LaSuiza, a burger with lettuce, tomato, carmelized onions, and cheeses. When it was ready the waiter brought it and, separately, a very small cast iron skillet where the cheeses had been prepared. After putting down the burger tray he mixed the cheeses together and drizzled them over the burger. I asked for the medium-sized patty to be cooked to Medium, but it came rare. Despite that it was delicious! I definitely recommend the ox burger patty - very lean. My wife's small-size ox burger, whose name I didn't record, came with arugula, tomato, carmelized onions, and provolone. Hers was cooked perfectly and she said it was terrific, the arugula offsetting the other flavors. My daughter ordered the Grilled Chicken Burger, which came with bacon, bourbon mayo, and gouda. She said it was a good meld of flavors and the chicken was cooked perfectly. I also ordered a sangria, which was one of the best I've had. All this goodness was offset by the waiter not asking us partway through the meal how everything was, and when we were done, the plates were cleared by another server. We waited about 10-15 minutes for the check, which was never brought, even though our waiter had walked by our table countless times and looked several times at the empty table. He did deliver and collect payment from another group who arrived after us. Two attempts to stop him were fruitless, and I ended up catching the eye of the only waitress I saw. She was very friendly and attentive. I would eat there again, but only if I didn't get the same waiter.

I would come back to Madrid only to visit this restaurant. Just wish I was strong longer so I could go back.  Thank you Monty and Adam.

title_review: The best meal in Madrid, hands down.
review_preview: My wife and I started with guacamole and plantain chips (easily the best guacamole we've ever had), moved to the goat cheese with pesto and honey (amazing), patatas bravas (delicious), pigs ears with paprika (different but tasty), and then the rabbit (unbelivably tender and so...
review_full: My wife and I started with guacamole and plantain chips (easily the best guacamole we've ever had), moved to the goat cheese with pesto and honey (amazing), patatas bravas (delicious), pigs ears with paprika (different but tasty), and then the rabbit (unbelivably tender and so flavorful). We finished off the meal with the mojito sorbet topped with white rum, so good. Our waiter, Hugo, was easily one of the nicest people we met in Madrid and could not have been any more helpful. Go to Gastromaquia--you won't be disappointed.

review_preview: In the Barrio de las Letras there is no shortage of restaurants. Italian fare, not as frequently found, tends to be more difficult to select. Well our friends in our current stay in Madrid suggested this place for a decent pizza. And there we went....
review_full: In the Barrio de las Letras there is no shortage of restaurants. Italian fare, not as frequently found, tends to be more difficult to select. Well our friends in our current stay in Madrid suggested this place for a decent pizza. And there we went. Little they knew, much less us, that the restaurant has an enchanting basement with multiple, exposed, brick-made vaults with tables in between, an interesting dining situation, indeed. Run by relative young people, the restaurant not only specializes in a small and select menu list but they also offer artisanal beers, including some brewed by themselves. And from our conversation, I can tell they do know their trade. Important to mention, their pizza is as artisanal as they get, thin-crusted delights perfectly cooked with fresh ingredients. And this was a surprising turn. All in all, not only we enjoyed with satisfaction a superior version of the italian inspired dish, but the service was adequate and the ambiance unforgettable. Thus, when in this city obsessed with food you need a break from the abundant spanish menu, do not hesitate to consider Brew Wild Pizza Bar, despite their somewhat kitsch name and the small entrance.

review_full: Found this restaurant on Trip advisor and it completely lived up to its reputation.  We called to book half an hour before and it was a good idea as it is a small and very popular restaurant that gets full quickly.  The staff were SO friendly and helpful taking the time to find out where we were from and going into fantastic detail (in English) about the menu dishes and the daily specials despite having just done the same minutes earlier for the table next to us. He helped us to scale back our choices so we didn't over order but could still have the opportunity to taste the dishes we wanted to. We ordered 5 dishes all reasonably priced and each was as good as the last. The place had a great relaxed atmosphere all down to the care and attention of the hard working staff and the fantastic tasting food. I rarely leave reviews. This place fully deserves its 5 star reputation

review_preview: I generally hate agreeing with people, and following the herd. But this place deserves all the great things people say about it. How can another review make any difference in swaying or even confirming opinion? Why even bother adding another rave notice? Indeed, why make...
review_full: I generally hate agreeing with people, and following the herd. But this place deserves all the great things people say about it. How can another review make any difference in swaying or even confirming opinion? Why even bother adding another rave notice? Indeed, why make it even harder to get a table here, once word meets critical mass, and it fully gains the recognition it deserves? But I went for only my second time last night, and I wanted to share my thoughts about WHY this place is such a phenomenon.  The food is undoubtedly excellent. From the regular dishes it serves the best: Quacamole I have ever tasted (tried twice, confirmed twice). The most interesting way of serving octopus (bar perhaps an octopus curry fresh from the sea I once had in Zanzibar) I have ever had, and certainly ever had in Spain. With a creamy potato foam.  The quite amazing Mojito sorbet, which is the essential way to finish a meal here. But last night I also sampled the special of Ortiguillas de mar - "deep-fried sea anemones". I've had this a few times down in Cadiz, which is famous for it. But these were the best I've tasted. There's a trick to doing these well, I learned from the owner, who explained that he had been researching corn flour - which provides the coating - in Galicia and Asturias, regions in the north of Spain. And he had found a really light flour that makes these delicate little treats something else.  Now, this might sound a bit nerdy, and of little importance. But for me it pointed to why I think this place is very special. Spain is very traditional in its approach to food, and certain regions are known for certain foods. The best ham comes from Extremadura; the best olive oil from Jaen, the best black pudding from Burgos, etc. These are articles of faith for the Spanish. And food tends to be cooked well or badly depending on how faithfully the chef sticks to the traditions of cooking the dish. Which rather stifles innovation, and means there's less cross-pollination from different regions. The chef is from Catalunia, Barcelona; but evidently has a very open mind about taking the best from everywhere, trying new things and evolving Spanish cuisine. He takes staples of the Spanish table - patatas bravas, etc. - and adds his own twist, and suddenly you realise how bored you have got with most of the staple tapas fare in Madrid.  That's the first thing, the chef's exploratory, innovative outlook. The second was the very fact that he bothered to explain this to me in a busy restaurant on a Saturday night. I was just another guiri (foreigner) punter, but his pride in his food and his enthusiasm to share this was impressive. He took the same care with every table. He explains everything on the menu in perfect English to every table, and makes everyone feel very welcome and cared for. You might forgive a chef of such creative flair to keep in the background, and let his food speak for itself. You might even forgive him a certain arrogance (not unknown in his profession). But instead, he adds exceptional, very personalised service to extraordinary quality and value.  This place deserves every plaudit. It deserves to be famous. Go there before it gets too famous (but not all at once, please). I dread the day when it is impossible to get a table.

title_review: Best Meal We Had In Madrid
review_preview: We tried this restaurant on a whim after reading interesting reviews about it.  It is about a 15 minute walk from central Madrid that requires walking through a busy but rather sketchy area, but proved to be well worth the effort.  It is located in...
review_full: We tried this restaurant on a whim after reading interesting reviews about it. It is about a 15 minute walk from central Madrid that requires walking through a busy but rather sketchy area, but proved to be well worth the effort. It is located in a narrow space with a small number of tables, and the owner / chef Hugo's friendly greeting and enthusiasm makes you feel welcome and valued instantly. There is a rather ancient menu in Spanish, but Hugo clearly enjoys translating not just the words but the intention behind the unique and creative dishes. The menu has traditional fare, variations on traditional fare and some very original creations. Our group of 3 couples particularly enjoyed the Guacamole with Plantain Chips, and the Fresh Tuna Tartare in a light mustard sauce. The atmosphere is basic, the dress very casual, and the servers young, happy and hard-working. After discussing the cuisine among ourselves, we agreed that the best description of the food would be "gourmet," despite the simple surroundings. An added bonus for the language-impaired is that Hugo has lived in The US and the UK, so he speaks English perfectly

review_preview: Encouraged by reviews on "Trip Advisor" we booked here for a "Special Night-out", and it turned out to be just that! Viewed from Calle Pelayo, "Gastromaquia" immediately registers as quite compact, and not exactly prepossessing . But what it may seem to lack in appearances,...
review_full: Encouraged by reviews on "Trip Advisor" we booked here for a "Special Night-out", and it turned out to be just that! Viewed from Calle Pelayo, "Gastromaquia" immediately registers as quite compact, and not exactly prepossessing . But what it may seem to lack in appearances, it more than makes-up in the quality of its deliciously tasty food offering, and notably also, in the warm, entertaining front-of-house presence of its co-owner, Hugo. Bear in mind, this place is tiny : a narrow, brightly decorated, noisy area with plastic tables & chairs -at a push it could seat 25 people. We were allocated a table at the back, were given Menus (en Espanol), and while waiting for our host, Hugo, to come and explain all to us, ordered some wine from the limited available choices. Hugo, and his co-owner Chef Ramon (they met at "Culinary School") are the stars of the show here. The former leads you through an item by item description (in English) of the many Tapas choices - a performance in itself - while his Partner behind the scenes, as we discovered, produces some of the most tasty food you could find in Madrid! Our quite conservative choices were "Foie con Tostas", a Rabbit dish, a Goat's Cheese dish, some Skewered Meat, and on Hugo's recommendation, a Guacamole concoction. We were impressed with the flavours in all cases - these guys are certainly a great advert for the concept that several smaller courses conjured-up by a talented Chef, can be far superior to larger plates in lesser hands. This was indeed food for highly enjoyable "grazing"! A glass of the "House White", a bottle of Ribera del Duero, some agua sin gas, + an espresso all added to our enjoyment. We were also fortunate to have an opportunity for a brief chat with Hugo later, when the ongoing demands for his attention eased-off a bit. He's an absolutely fascinating man, proud of what he does, knowledgeable about Spain's history, more than willing to debate, and generous in openly acknowledging this is not a "one man show" - both he, and his Partner, Ramon, are both from Barcelona, by the way. Our Bill for this evening - highly entertaining on many levels - was a more than reasonable Euro 66-15 (before adding a Tip for our attentive Waiter). We departed, very satisfied!

title_review: Don't Judge a Book by its Cover
review_preview: This place was unbelieable.  We had heard amazing reviews so we went to see what it was all about and on our way past a handful of trendy and indulging restaurants.  When we saw Gastromaquia we almost turned around but the waiter was very insistent...
review_full: This place was unbelieable. We had heard amazing reviews so we went to see what it was all about and on our way past a handful of trendy and indulging restaurants. When we saw Gastromaquia we almost turned around but the waiter was very insistent and translated the menu for us. Everything sounded good so we stayed. Much to our disbelief this place was INCREDIBLE. Amazing tuna tartar to start with, came with dried banana slice chips and hard chips. Next we got mussels and they were the best mussels I have ever had in my life. I'm a huge seafood fanatic and wow muy bueno. It's served with bread so once you finish the mussels dip the bread in the sauce, it really tops it off. Lastly we got the octopus which I wasn't a huge fan of but I'm not a huge octopus fan in the first place.... but my friend loved it said it was one of the best ever. It has melted cheese and sauces all over it. THEN to top it off they gave us a complementary mojito dessert --to die for. Mint ice cream drenched in bacardi... This is a must. VERY unassuming.

title_review: First night in Madrid, off to a great start
review_preview: We ate here on our first night in Madrid. Just got off the plane and straight to this fun tapas bar, that was just a couple of steps from our hotel at Sol. If this is any indication to what the food here is like...
review_full: We ate here on our first night in Madrid. Just got off the plane and straight to this fun tapas bar, that was just a couple of steps from our hotel at Sol. If this is any indication to what the food here is like I think we are off to a great start. I will start with the service. We were a group of twelve. Made reservations in advance for 23:30. arrived 20 min late due to delay at the airport but were still welcomed with a smile . restaurant was packed. Laura, our lovely waitress came and took our very big order Helping out with our decisions. Everything came out at once. no mistakes. The food- absolutely delicious and Nicely presented. We tried many of the dishes on the menu and highly recommend the following: Pesto stuffed borata with cherry tomatoes.  Grilled pork tenderloin, ceviche and fried calamari. BBQ Chicken wings were also tasty. Only dish that was just fine was the sesame tuna tataki which was a bit bland. Otherwise great food served to the middle of the table to share. Portion size was pretty big for tapas and I recommend up to two dishes pp if you are hungry. price is very reasonable ranging between 3-8 euros for most dishes. Drinks were good too and had plenty of alcohol. Mojitos, Daiquiris and caipirinhas were all served in big glasses for 7 euros each. Atmosphere- young crowd, on the load side.  All and all a very nice experience.

review_full: I am unable to find the branch round the corner from Gran Via so unsure if this is the exact restaurant we visited as Steakburger is a chain of restaurants. The food was that good we went 2 nights in a row. Compliments to the chef the burgers are the best burgers I have ever tasted. The mozzarella sticks are amazing and the food comes to the table so quick!! I also recommend the frozen daiquiris. The first night the waitress was lovely and the lady did her best to try some English. The second night we went (Monday 7th Sept) the young waiter who seemed to be the only one there at 8pm (the place was quiet and other staff arrived later) he had a face like thunder. Didn't greet us with a smile, couldn't care less about what we actually wanted. He came over to take our order and I asked him politely if he would like our drink order first or food and he said 'I don't care'. This made my boyfriend and I feel very uncomfortable and felt it was a hassle to ask him for another drink. So we left as soon as we ate out food and our night was ruined. We couldn't wait to leave. I would have given 5 stars if it hadn't been for the waiters attitude. It stunk basically. We gave the chef his top on the way out as he deserved it more.

One aspect which seemed a bit funny was that nearly all customers spoke English... while it is located in a touristic restaurant area but i did not experience it in other places around. It maybe is because normally Spannish people eat tapas in different setting and this is more catered to other type customers... in any case the food was yummy, the service great and the price very correct. I will return when possible.
