After 30 minutes we said something to one of the gals, and she seemed genuinely shocked and immediately rushed out some...
review_full: They screwed up...Twice...Big time! #1 We got our wine pretty quickly...then we waited...and waited...and waited...people seated after us were getting their tapas before ours. After 30 minutes we said something to one of the gals, and she seemed genuinely shocked and immediately rushed out some tapas of croquettes and fried eggplant. Our order somehow vanished! #2 We ordered again, the chicken and seafood paella for two. 20 minutes later we got our paella, but it was only chicken, doh! They apologized, and in another 20 minutes we got finally got our chicken and seafood paella, yay! Paella takes time to make properly. It was delicious! €26 Chicken and Seafood Paella for two...so good! I'm not an expert, but everything appeared to be cooked perfectly. Hopefully they don't lose or screw up your order.  €3 Fried Eggplant slices with honey...crispy, sweet, and delicious! €3 Ham croquettes...rich, creamy, fatty, and deep fried gooey happiness.  Despite the failures, the staff was extremely sorry and friendly throughout our drawn out 2+ hour dining experience. Luckily we had no other plans that night. Some of the drinks and tapas did not appear on the final bill, so all was well.

title_review: Great food, lovely staff, brilliant atmosphere.
review_preview: We turned up late looking for a table and had to wait for one to become available. The front of house girl was lovely and chatted to us while we waited and offered us drinks. We decided to head home before our table was ready...
review_full: We turned up late looking for a table and had to wait for one to become available. The front of house girl was lovely and chatted to us while we waited and offered us drinks. We decided to head home before our table was ready (it was 1am and the place was jumping!). The manager (Francesco?) came out to apologise for our wait and offered to make a reservation for the next night. He also refused to take any money for the sangria's we'd ordered while waiting that night.  We returned the following night for a fabulous meal which was beautifully prepared and very reasonably priced. The staff made us feel so welcome and really made our night. Would highly recommend this great little tapas bar!

When our meal was done, they brought over 2 after meal drinks and one special one for my 13yr old nephew. The drinks where served in test tubes and presented in a mason jar. This restaurant is a must, if you are in Madrid. We will definitely be back, if we ever come back to Madrid.

title_review: Amazing restaurant, amazing food, and a wonderful staff! Don't miss it!
review_preview: My wife and I just returned from our Spanish vacation and made it a point to come on here and review this restaurant because we had such a wonderful experience here. It was our last night in Madrid and we had not yet had paella...
review_full: My wife and I just returned from our Spanish vacation and made it a point to come on here and review this restaurant because we had such a wonderful experience here. It was our last night in Madrid and we had not yet had paella so our hotel desk clerk recommended a place as there are very many places in the area that offer paella on the menu. However, after checking the reviews on tripadvisor we found Rosi La Loca and wow how lucky were we. There was a 10 minute wait without a reservation but once we were seated the sangria flowed deliciously, the atmosphere was awesome and the paella was freaking delicious! Our waiter Monty was probably the best, most welcoming waiter I have ever had the pleasure of meeting and completely sealed the whole experience for us. Rosi La Loca should feel very proud and lucky to have such a wonderfully polite, conversational, and professional employee. The restaurant was very clean and has more seating than what is seen from the street. Although the seating is a bit tight, it gives way for great conversations with seated neighbors who are from other parts of the world. We only had the paella and sangria but every dish on tables nearby looked and smelled delicious as well. Overall I would say this gem of a restaurant should definitely be on your list of "must do" for Madrid. You will not be disappointed!!

review_preview: It was our last dinner of the trip to Spain, and probably one of the best ones during the 2 weeks we traveled. Freshest ingredients, simple and superb taste. To start we had the sweetest heirloom tomatoes with anchovies - great! The only surprise was...
review_full: It was our last dinner of the trip to Spain, and probably one of the best ones during the 2 weeks we traveled. Freshest ingredients, simple and superb taste. To start we had the sweetest heirloom tomatoes with anchovies - great! The only surprise was that anchovies were 3 euro for one, kind of overboard in my book... but very delicious! Fantastic vegetables and aromatic mushrooms - everything is freshest of the season. We also had a tuna belly, which was superbly prepared. We also loved the atmosphere and ambiance of the place. It was full of locals and just such a nice crowd overall, it was nice to watch them - beautiful people. Will definitely go there again, next time we are in Madrid.

review_preview: I was living in Madrid for a few months and ended up here by recommendation of my roommate. It is a wonderful restaurant! The food is so unique; their menu has some classic Spanish items like patatas bravas, but also has innovative tapas like clams...
review_full: I was living in Madrid for a few months and ended up here by recommendation of my roommate. It is a wonderful restaurant! The food is so unique; their menu has some classic Spanish items like patatas bravas, but also has innovative tapas like clams with a masala sauce. The owner, who has worked in New York and DC and speaks flawless English, came out to speak with my party and explain the menu each time I went (I ended up going again for a friend's birthday and took my parents when they visited). The whole staff is so eager to help and so passionate about food, and I had a great experience each time. It's one of the best experiences you'll have in Madrid. And don't skip on dessert!

Great atmosphere - good for groups and couples. We will return!

review_preview: Do not be fooled by the unassuming exterior of this restaurant. I was a little skeptical upon arrival, but this certainly is a hidden treasure. First off, (1 of) the owner/server is very welcoming, and really spends time explaining the menu and making suggestions, although...
review_full: Do not be fooled by the unassuming exterior of this restaurant. I was a little skeptical upon arrival, but this certainly is a hidden treasure. First off, (1 of) the owner/server is very welcoming, and really spends time explaining the menu and making suggestions, although by no means pushy. They have an interesting menu, and everything is delicious! We started with patatas bravas, which were good, but the goat cheese with pesto and honey was TO DIE FOR! It was rich, but man oh man was it scrumptious! Next we had the tikka masala mussels, and sliced octopus in some sort of cheese sauce. Unfortunately, I had somewhat higher expectations for the mussels…the seasoning wasn't quite right, and it was a little watery, but still good. The octopus was done very well, nice and tender, with a nice balance of spicy and creamy. Finally, we finished a mojito sorbet, which was so refreshing. Having lived in South Florida for several years, I was astounded that we hadn't seen this on a menu before. It is very creative, and was an excellent end to our delicious meal!

review_preview: I am so very glad we found this place.  We ate here twice on our trip to Madrid.  The restaurant is small and cozy and the food incredible.  The first night we ate here was a weekend, and the place was pretty crowded so we...
review_full: I am so very glad we found this place. We ate here twice on our trip to Madrid. The restaurant is small and cozy and the food incredible. The first night we ate here was a weekend, and the place was pretty crowded so we waited for a table. The second time was a mid-week dinner and the place was not as busy. So I would definitely suggest making a reservation on weekends. The food was simple and delicious. Ugo, the owner, is a gracious and humble guy just putting out great food every night. He spent time in the U.S., so his english is fluent, and he walked us through the menu, made spot on recommendations and accurately judged how much our party should order. There was not a single dish we did not care for or even thought to be merely average. Prices are also extremely reasonable, especially for the city. I will definitely be returning on my next visit to Madrid.

review_full: Went here with my parents and we loved it! It's slightly off Gran Via, but the street that it's on is a little shady. Small place, so we made a reservation for 830. We were the first there, but the place quickly filled up and we kept looking around to see what everyone else was ordering. The owner Hugh is super friendly and translated the whole menu and made some suggestions. We had the goat cheese/honey starter which was amazing, followed by pork skewers, salmon salad, curry mussels, patatas bravas, and 3 different desserts. Had a bottle of wine as well, so for 3 the price wasn't that bad at 85 euros. Fabulous, unique food! A must try for Madrid.

title_review: Expensive food, atmosphere as dead as a corpse.
review_preview: We ate at this place due to the reviews on TripAdvisor, This place is really small and cramped. Inside the tables are really close to each other, the decor is poor and its feels like a cheap cafe,  During our meal the electric cut out...
review_full: We ate at this place due to the reviews on TripAdvisor,  This place is really small and cramped. Inside the tables are really close to each other, the decor is poor and its feels like a cheap cafe,   During our meal the electric cut out about 4 times which was irritating to say the least, the atmosphere is a dead as a corpse. The food although tasty is expensive for just Tapas. We had some deep fried banana thing, goats cheese with basil pesto, and some meat things they call Fajitas, all of which you can get at other Tapas places for about half the price.  The food is tasty however and the staff are very helpful and some speak good English.  After we ate our meal and paid 50 euros, we were kindly asked to leave straight away as they needed the table, bit of a joke.  But seriously if your in Madrid there are so many other better places to eat.  Would i go back? No chance!!

title_review: Almost as good as the original
review_preview: After being almost impossible to get a table in their location at Calle Palencia, we decided to try their new restaurant in Calle Cristóbal Bordiú, 5. As soon as we walked in, the delicious smell of their cooking filled the air and made our mouth...
review_full: After being almost impossible to get a table in their location at Calle Palencia, we decided to try their new restaurant in Calle Cristóbal Bordiú, 5.  As soon as we walked in, the delicious smell of their cooking filled the air and made our mouth water. I like the way they seemed to place family with children in one area and another one without, which is kind of great. After a warm welcoming, we got the menus and this is something they need to improve. We got colour photocopies, with even a page on its own (I guess their budget is big enough to order some proper menus) I really think they should improve this (something they should also do in the original restaurant). Quick service and delicious food almost exactly as in Calle Palencia. However, we were a bit shocked by how small and thin our desserts were. I order the pistachio cheesecake and it was so tiny that it couldn’t even stand on it own. That’s the second thing to improve. Last, it would be nice to place a sign for the female toilets since there none and it’s a bit confusing to know which one is the right door when there are a few doors in the same area. I’ll be back but I still find a bit better the original one though

title_review: Fantastico delicious inspirational rico wholesome! The best experience!
review_preview: This restaurant restored my faith in the out comes of following positive reviews and eating somewhere you haven't before. I adventured to this little hole in the wall in a quite street a few blocks down from the Gran Via, early in the evening to...
review_full: This restaurant restored my faith in the out comes of following positive reviews and eating somewhere you haven't before. I adventured to this little hole in the wall in a quite street a few blocks down from the Gran Via, early in the evening to secure a seat and being the only one there I sat by the bar. This only added to my positive experience for the waiting staff were so welcoming, friendly and attentive I didn't feel I was eating alone, but amongst friends. This is something very special when you travel alone and therefore eat out alone. Besides the excellent service and welcome when I arrived, each plate that came was so creative, with an amazing blend of textures and flavors. You can tell there are some brains working in the kitchen to produce such delicacies. The grilled goats cheese was so rich and wholesome with a green sweet sauce that set off the dish. Having fresh crispy baguette served with the meal provided the perfect accompaniment and there is nothing more tasty then creamy cheese on same day fresh bread. The mushroom croquettes were so creamy with the thinnest of crispy batter on the outside. Compliments of the kitchen I had the fortune of trying their tomato stuffed with guacamole croquette which was so fresh and innovative.  An advice, if after all the plates your so full you couldn't eat another thing... then you must ignore this feeling and try the chocolate whip! Its like eating chocolate air with crunchy croutons and a hint of foreign salt. Its so light you can enjoy the flavour without feeling any fuller.... now for the palat cleanser MOJITO SORBET. Zingy combination of what tasted like mint, lemon and a shot of bacardi poured over the top. A house top secret recipe that is the perfect final compliment to your meal experience at Gastromaquia. And if you don't speak spanish never fear the staff happily take their time to explain eveything on the menu, whether it be in english or spanish. This is a restaurant that values customer service and experience.  Thank you for a lovely evening in your unique restaurant! I was made to feel so welcome (and even a little spoilt) and enjoyed every mouthful!  Carpe Diem don't miss the opportunity of Gastromaguia!

title_review: Fabulous food and service to match!
review_preview: We loved our meal at Gastromaquia.  The food was creative and full of flavour - a great twist on some classic Spanish dishes. Definitely try the tuna carpaccio and the goats cheese with honey - delicious. And for dessert our faves were the chocolate 'foam'...
review_full: We loved our meal at Gastromaquia. The food was creative and full of flavour - a great twist on some classic Spanish dishes. Definitely try the tuna carpaccio and the goats cheese with honey - delicious. And for dessert our faves were the chocolate 'foam' and the mojito sorbet.  The real gem was our waiter Hugo who happens to be one of the owners. He speaks Spanish, French and perfect English and took the time to explain the menu and his passion for food.  It is only a small restaurant and quite understated in its decor but the food speaks for itself.  Highly recommend a visit - and make sure you make a reservation!

review_preview: My son who is studying in Madrid found this restaurant.  We rounded the corner and I was not impressed by the interior, however we decided to give it a shot.  Let me tell you it would have been a horrible mistake to have walked away...
review_full: My son who is studying in Madrid found this restaurant. We rounded the corner and I was not impressed by the interior, however we decided to give it a shot. Let me tell you it would have been a horrible mistake to have walked away tonight!!!!! This is a true foodie place. We had the curry mussels, rendition of carpaccio with blue cheese/figs/balsamic/anchovies, black pig skewers and calamari with whipped potato ( you would have thought it was cheese!). The wine is regional and very well priced. The finale was a mojito sorbet that three of us shared....definitely cleansed our palates! The food was as good as it gets in NYC or Boston (sorry homie chefs!).

title_review: Good service and food, limited menu, not much ambiance
review_preview: I had high expectations based on other reviews here, but I came away a little disappointed.The restaurant is downstairs in a hotel, towards the rear and away from the front windows, behind the bar area.  Unfortunately, this means it feels like the basement it...
review_full: I had high expectations based on other reviews here, but I came away a little disappointed. The restaurant is downstairs in a hotel, towards the rear and away from the front windows, behind the bar area. Unfortunately, this means it feels like the basement it is, and the white decor doesn't make up for it. Service is shared with the bar area, but it was very good (I did come at a quiet time at 20:30 on a Wednesday).  The menu had four meat dishes, four fish dishes, shared plates, and some less expensive pasta and vegetarian entrées. Five different wines were available by the glass. Service was prompt and attentive. My tuna tataki was well prepared, and the waiter's recommendation for dessert and orujo was also good. I didn't think the meal was particularly expensive either. So while the food and service were quite good, I just came away disappointed by the sterile decor, lack of ambiance, Muzak, and limited menu. So minus one star for that.

title_review: Wonderful experience, good food, fabulous people!
review_preview: I don't usually write restaurant reviews but felt I had to tonight. After a long day sightseeing Toledo, my mom (78 years old, first time in Europe, doesn't speak/understand Spanish, and vegetarian) and I (been traveling in Spain for a month, understand somewhat but do...
review_full: I don't usually write restaurant reviews but felt I had to tonight. After a long day sightseeing Toledo, my mom (78 years old, first time in Europe, doesn't speak/understand Spanish, and vegetarian) and I (been traveling in Spain for a month, understand somewhat but do not speak Spanish well, mostly vegetarian but will eat fish) planned a dinner out in Madrid in a vegan restaurant that had been recommended. Only problem was when we got there, they were closed for vacation. With no other plans, we came across La Portuguesa Taberna, which was in the same neighborhood as where we were staying. Based on previous reviews, we decided to check it out. Me (in very poor, Spanglish): "my mom is a vegetarian, do you have any vegetarian dishes on your menu?" Them: "???" Not exactly sure what they said but the gist of it was "sure, of course". They proceeded to make her a delicious rice and mushroom dish (not on the menu) and I got a dish that the owner recommended (didn't catch the name) which was bacalao (salt cod) with potatoes, onions and egg, along with a fabulous Portuguese red table wine. The owners and chef (I think husband and wife, maybe?) were unbelievably gracious, kind, helpful and understanding, and our meal was wonderful. Mom and I had a memorable experience at this lovely little place.

review_preview: We arrived at Sichuan exactly when they opened for dinner at 7:30 pm to find a line of people waiting for the gates to go up. We knew right then that we were in for something great. We ordered the Mapo Tofu, the eggplant in...
review_full: We arrived at Sichuan exactly when they opened for dinner at 7:30 pm to find a line of people waiting for the gates to go up. We knew right then that we were in for something great. We ordered the Mapo Tofu, the eggplant in garlic sauce and the beef noodle soup and we were blown away by both the appearance and the vibrant flavors of each dish. Beware: these dishes are SPICY - we love spicy food and only ordered medium spice, but it was extremely hot. If you’re looking for an alternative to tapas in Madrid, you don’t want to miss this place. If you go, you might miss it because it’s down an alley that’s not so easy to find off the Gran Via.

review_preview: My husband and I found ourselves with a four hour stopover in Madrid following a delayed flight. Luckily it was around dinner time and luckily we found Alabaster via the Michelin guide! The service was impeccable, they were very conscious and understanding of our time...
review_full: My husband and I found ourselves with a four hour stopover in Madrid following a delayed flight. Luckily it was around dinner time and luckily we found Alabaster via the Michelin guide! The service was impeccable, they were very conscious and understanding of our time constraint and the food was prepared extremely quickly. But that did not deter from the A-class meal this restaurant quite obviously consistently provides. We chose to share dishes and they very kindly prepared them on separate plates which was a nice, very “fine dining” touch. The tomato salad was incredibly fresh and the combination of flavours was very special - clean and crisp. The prawn that came with the egg and potato was quite simply spectacular on its own, but even better when eaten with its accompaniments. A true example of when a restaurant uses top quality ingredients. The slow cooked Galician rib of beef was a true delight and we had rarely had such a nice combination with the fresh herbs. Finally, the house dessert of lemon, the most heavenly meringue, and almond was absolutely DIVINE. We were so incredibly pleased to have stumbled upon this gastronomic delight in Madrid!!!

The merluza pili deserves a special mention - great taste and every millimetre of the fish was cooked to perfection. The zamburina and huevos poche also deserve a special mention. And the wines chosen were  And overall the restaurant has an elegant, effortless and warm ambience. If you're in madrid definitely worth visiting more than once. (and in my opinion it is very fairly priced!)

title_review: Great food, racist service. Avoid if you're young or brown.
review_preview: we had a booking on 2nd Jan. We expected a wholesome michelin experience, that unfortunately stopped at the food. As a young, brown couple, this is what we saw : a) nobody came and offered to take our coats, they were left strewn on the...
review_full: we had a booking on 2nd Jan. We expected a wholesome michelin experience, that unfortunately stopped at the food. As a young, brown couple, this is what we saw : a) nobody came and offered to take our coats, they were left strewn on the vacant chair beside us (versus practically disrobing other guests at the door) b) server comes up and asks if i want beer or wine. Ok, can i see the menu please ? Sure he said. I never saw him or the menu ever again. Every other table had a wine sommelier come up, taste the wine, and provide their recommendation. except us. we didn't even get a drink. d) every other table had a small tableside stool that was brought and placed beside the lady for her bag/accessories. except us - make do with the vacant chair again. e) we had to keep calling for service, the waiters seem to stand and stare vacantly into space. Didn't seem to be a problem for the european couple besides us. How's the food ? great. How's the experience ? Absolute disgrace in this day and age. We paid over a $100 for a tasty meal with a generous serving of racism.

title_review: Excellent restaurant both for food and staff
review_preview: Had an amazing dinner here last night. Menu is separated into four sections: tapas/small plates, salads (perhaps vegetarian? Admit I skipped over), sea and land. We split three tapas - sardines on toast (elevated with what I think was a sun dried tomato “jelly”), sea...
review_full: Had an amazing dinner here last night. Menu is separated into four sections: tapas/small plates, salads (perhaps vegetarian? Admit I skipped over), sea and land. We split three tapas - sardines on toast (elevated with what I think was a sun dried tomato “jelly”), sea bass tartar with fried egg, and cockles that made me change my mind on clams a bit (they were that fresh and good). I had baby kid (rack of) and my husband had hake with the best side of potatoes and kafir lime cream. For dessert, a texture of chocolates for me. Surprisingly his choice of carrot and beets as a dessert was one of the best things all night. Wine by the glass here was insane. 5€ for gems recommended by our sommelier by the glass, all from small vineyards. All incredible.

title_review: Insanely good! 3rd visit in 2 months and still can't get enough!

Needless to say I don't recommend this place to anyone steer clear of this place.

review_preview: We try to have a Chinese meal at least once wherever we go. This venue was convenient to our hotel, and as many of the customers were Chinese it seemed like a good recommendation. We got a table and menus without a problem, but the...
review_full: We try to have a Chinese meal at least once wherever we go. This venue was convenient to our hotel, and as many of the customers were Chinese it seemed like a good recommendation. We got a table and menus without a problem, but the noise built up quickly and made the visit unpleasant. The manager was shouting at staff and running up and down the restaurant and food wasn't coming out very quickly. We ordered a crispy spicy beef and prawns in oyster sauce. The rice came quickly. The prawns a bit later, and then the spicy beef. We were warned the beef was very spicy when it was served. It was so spicy that it wasn't edible - and I'm not averse to a spice or two. It looked very good, but sadly we had to send it back. There was no attempt to replace it, and although we'd have been happy to pay for it having ordered it, we weren't charged for it. I think the language issue didn't help - Chinese staff in Spain trying to speak a little English, and not understanding my attempt to speak Spanish was confusing.

title_review: I don't know a better Italian in Madrid
review_preview: I've been to a fair few Italian restaurants in the capital and for me this is the best one for a number of reasons. Firstly it is authentic; you can even see the Italian cooks in the kitchen preparing the food. Secondly it is really...
review_full: I've been to a fair few Italian restaurants in the capital and for me this is the best one for a number of reasons. Firstly it is authentic; you can even see the Italian cooks in the kitchen preparing the food. Secondly it is really good value; with the menu del dia (availabe during the week) at 8.90e (+2e with a dessert), or a good sized pizza from 5.50e. I have been back a couple of times and the menu del dia changes so you get to try a variety of different dishes if you decide to go back. The menu del dia always has 2 options for starters and 2 for the main course, but the general menu with the pizzas always stays the same. The service is good but it is a popular place so I'd advise booking for the evening or getting there promptly for lunch. The one negative is that is is situated in the Mercado Anton Martin, literally in passageway between stalls so you will have people walking by constantly and the majority of the seating is on high stools - but the food more than makes up for it.

review_preview: This is a little but down a side street but don't be put off it's well worth seeking out. We arrived around 8:45 and there was nobody seated in the restaurant. I say this because when we left around 9:45 it was jammed full with...
review_full: This is a little but down a side street but don't be put off it's well worth seeking out. We arrived around 8:45 and there was nobody seated in the restaurant. I say this because when we left around 9:45 it was jammed full with a queue out the door ! Many restaurants in Spain don't even open until 8:30, they like to eat late in Madrid. They were very busy with takeaway trade. We both ordered pizza and shared a salad. They have two sizes of pizza which is good. Speaking no Spanish they were able to give us an older menu in English so we could figure out what we wanted on the current Spanish menu. They added and took off things from the pizzas we wanted. Both were tasty. A large pizza, a smaller pizza, a lovely salad with a water and two large beers amounted to €37. Very tasty food. Service was efficient and they tried their best to accommodate us and our lack of Spanish. I would definitely eat here again.

title_review: A real Italian with real good food :D
review_preview: I discovered this place during the Madrid Food Tour and immediately realised that I wasn't chomping on just any tapa of porchetta... It was an authentic, scrumptious porchetta made by the two owners of the stand. The real deal, as they say. So the next...
review_full: I discovered this place during the Madrid Food Tour and immediately realised that I wasn't chomping on just any tapa of porchetta... It was an authentic, scrumptious porchetta made by the two owners of the stand. The real deal, as they say.  So the next day, I went back for more, dragging my Italian boyfriend with me just to double check the quality.  We had Spaghetti alla Chitarra with duck ragu', pizza with buffalo mozzarella and more porchetta. All the above were made to order, extremely good (ok, the pizza could have hosted more mozzarella, but we totally understand) and true to their roots. The wine selection was particularly laudable. The two Italian men running the place were friendly, efficient and professional, chatting with the customers but not too invasive, leaving us space to eat but always there if we needed anything.  A great place that we both recommend for foreigners who want to try real Italian food without the hassle of a sit-down restaurant, Madrileños that want to try real Italian food without the doubt of being duped and Italians that want to try real Italian food that isn't the usual carbonara, "espaguettis boloñesa" or thick, chewy pizza.

review_preview: Piccola Napoli - what a surprise today. Popular place , nicely renovated. Pizzas and Pasta just great. In particular pasta lovely. Here you can eat a right and perfectly prepared Carbonara. Authentic napoletan pizzas -the simple ones as eaten in Southern Italy and Naples. Also...
review_full: Piccola Napoli - what a surprise today. Popular place , nicely renovated. Pizzas and Pasta just great. In particular pasta lovely. Here you can eat a right and perfectly prepared Carbonara. Authentic napoletan pizzas -the simple ones as eaten in Southern Italy and Naples. Also fantasy pizzas mainly invented outside Italy ( by italians). Close your eyes and you feel like sitting in the spanish quarter....in Naples. All that you can have for a real fab price. Not a big wine selection just some simple bottles of course from southern Italy. Daily menu is salad, pizza or pasta and a small dessert for 10,50.-E. How is that possible for such a tasteful and good pasta.......secrets of Naples........

title_review: Unassuming pizzeria with quality Italian fare at very fair prices
review_preview: This little Italian pizzeria doesn't have much by way of cosmetic appeal, and it doesn't need it.  The menu is just long enough to offer variety, without reaching the point where they're not good at any of the things they offer; the pizzas are tasty...
review_full: This little Italian pizzeria doesn't have much by way of cosmetic appeal, and it doesn't need it. The menu is just long enough to offer variety, without reaching the point where they're not good at any of the things they offer; the pizzas are tasty and affordable; the bruschette were great. The service is friendly enough, and the overall experience is just right. I wanted an authentic Italian pizzeria experience, and Piccola Napoli delivered. I will definitely return when I'm in the mood for simple, affordable, tasty Italian pizza.

title_review: The best slap in the face you could ask for
review_preview: My Brazilian girlfriend never tires of telling me, as we sit down for tortilla and croquetas, that 'tapas' is Portuguese for a slap around the chops. For once, eating at Amicis one late Saturday evening in November, I could see there might be some Latin...
review_full: My Brazilian girlfriend never tires of telling me, as we sit down for tortilla and croquetas, that 'tapas' is Portuguese for a slap around the chops. For once, eating at Amicis one late Saturday evening in November, I could see there might be some Latin root connection there.  For sure, the food is good - it has to be, it's Madrid and competition is expansive, loud and broad - and around the shiny Mercado de San Miguel the standard bodegas and tabernas are dolled up even more to attract the tourist dollar. Amicis sits between the Mercado (fun for a drink and some finger food before the main event) and Flamenco Las Carboneras (go for the incredible dancing and don't be put off by the tourist crowd), and if it wasn't for recommendations from friends at home, we might have passed by the front door for a shinier, more obvious establishment. But boy, were we glad we didn't. As I said, the food was good. The ubiquitous patatas bravas were the best we ate in the city, the padron peppers perfectly charred, and our carnivorous Dutch friends assured us the duck pancakes were delicious. Many more tapas plates came and went, with the kitchen attentive to our mixed dietary requirements and changing things up so my girlfriend and I could try things, and the waiting staff always happy with suggestions and modifications. We paused while we regained some composure, drank some more of the well recommended house red, and then got down to the mains. I ordered an Asian salad, and it was fine but I think I just wanted more tapas. My girlfriend's burrata starter as a main was a success, and the Dutchies made short work of the on-point, medium rare wasabi fillet steak. A nod to the management for allowing their international team to stamp the mark of their respective homelands on the food and signature cocktails; fusion is nothing new but I always like to see further east and Southern American influence on European classics and here it really made things stand out. More cocktails, a sharing platter of sugary things to give us some spark back, plus a traditional digestif, and we were about ready to stride out into the night again. But this wasn't even the half of it. Yes, Amicis is about food. And drink. But it's mainly about being with friends, having fun, and not letting the business of transacting with a restaurant get in the way of that. In fact, Amicis makes it their business to enhance that friendly experience, as the name suggests. Fabio, the owner/manager was attentive all night, from welcome, to tour of the building, through business advice to my entrepreneur girlfriend, on hand but not crowding, to final drinks on the house and being sent on our way with a VIP pass to the front of the queue for the media darling club around the corner. Perhaps my head the next day was the 'Portuguese tapas' slap around the face, but in the company of Fabio and his excellent, warm and welcoming team, it was just handshakes, hugs and slaps on the back.  I understand why friends back in the UK recommended Amicis in a city of superlative dining experiences, and now I will too. The food is good. The price point is fair for the area. If you want Michelin star or to stretch your euro to the last cent, then you should look elsewhere. But if you want to dine with friends, laugh, and leave as one of the family, Amicis will puts its arm around you, fill you with good cheer, and send you smiling and feeling at home out under the Madrid moon sky.

review_full: We were expecting a great dinner, based on the menu options and TA reviews, however we were quite disappointed. They didn't have the ensalada Rusa or the wok salad...so we skipped the starters and ordered the grilled octopus and the rigatoni with truffles and cheese. The octopus was a bit slimy, though the flavor was OK, but my wife's truffled pasta was missing the main ingredient, truffles! We called our server and explained the issue and they took the dish back. We were sitting right across from the kitchen and it looked like they were looking for the truffle oil, don't think they found it. Thd dish came back but really lacked thd truffle flavor that we expected. We did have a good bottle of rosé though!  The service was fine, staff was friendly and the place has a great vibe. Maybe it was an off night or we made the wrong choices, we might try it again another night.

title_review: Fantastic meal at a good price
review_preview: I was in Madrid with work colleagues last week and one of my British colleagues suggested Rosi La Loca for Paella based on tripadvisor reviews.  I must say that, being Portuguese and having visited Spain in numerous occasions, I was sceptical when I got to...
review_full: I was in Madrid with work colleagues last week and one of my British colleagues suggested Rosi La Loca for Paella based on tripadvisor reviews. I must say that, being Portuguese and having visited Spain in numerous occasions, I was sceptical when I got to the restaurant and saw palm trees and pink flamingos so I did not expect what happened next,. We were very well looked after and were given a table in a secluded room. All for ourselves. The service was impeccable throughout the meal. The food, well... We had quite a few dishes as we decided to share amongst the group. The key highlights of the meal were the Burrata inyectada con pesto, bombones cherry y rúcula.(Burrata injected with pesto), the paellas (we had a vegetables one, a seafood and and surf and turf one) and all of the desserts as we tried them all. The lesson I learnt was not to judge a book by its cover.

review_preview: Make reservations!!! When our party of 5 walked up to the Rosi La Loca they were turning people away because they did not have reservations. Mind you we had just passed quite a few places that were asking us to come in. From this moment...
review_full: Make reservations!!! When our party of 5 walked up to the Rosi La Loca they were turning people away because they did not have reservations. Mind you we had just passed quite a few places that were asking us to come in. From this moment on I knew we were in for a treat. The hostess was so sweet. She lead us to a cozy table downstairs. Downstairs we were welcomed by Isabel and Gerardo. Isabel and Gerardo made our night seamless and made our meal special by their attention. We had different rounds of tapas all of which were amazing. We stared with the Crispy Eggplant with Honey, Rosi's Wings with Mango and Chili Sauce, Croquetas de jamón de "La Rosi", Baby Squid Bao and Calamari with Ali Oli. Every single tapa was extremely tasty. The we had the Paella de Marisco. We had been in Spain for 13 days and were looking for the best Paella and we finally found it at Rosi's!!! Creamy and tasty it cannot be missed. For dessert we had the Crazy Liquid Deconstructed Cheesecake and Caramelized Cinnamon Brioche with Ice Cream. YUM!!!  Also the house wines matched our meal perfectly. We have two days left in Madrid and are hoping to come back before we go home and try the rest of the menu!!!

review_preview: We were looking for a place to dine during one of the busiest week-ends in Madrid, the celebration of World Pride. Every place we stopped at said they were fully booked despite the restaurants being more than 80% empty. Then we turn the corner and...
review_full: We were looking for a place to dine during one of the busiest week-ends in Madrid, the celebration of World Pride. Every place we stopped at said they were fully booked despite the restaurants being more than 80% empty. Then we turn the corner and found Alabaster. Nothing prepared us for the excellence of this restaurant. Exquisite and modern decor, great service and a modern take on Galician food. The fresh Navajas on a mango and passion fruit chutney were divine and the fish was fresh, flavorful and perfectly cooked. for desert we had torrejas which were absolutely wonderful and a special treat for me as I had not enjoyed them since I was a child. Pricey but totally worth it!

review_preview: Very much enjoyed this restaurant close to our hotel in the Paseo Del Prado district. Starters are available as half portions and two of us enjoyed three half portions of mussel croquettes, scallops and sardines.Main courses chosen were seafood rice and hake and both...
review_full: Very much enjoyed this restaurant close to our hotel in the Paseo Del Prado district.  Starters are available as half portions and two of us enjoyed three half portions of mussel croquettes, scallops and sardines. Main courses chosen were seafood rice and hake and both were excellent. The seafood rice had great flavour and plenty of shellfish. The hake was exceptional - beautifully cooked, glazed in great sauce balanced by the lemon/lime pil-pil and spinach. Desserts of cafe pannacotta and chocolate, orange macaron were great and beautifully presented. There's a huge wine list covering all types and prices. Service was very professional yet friendly with good English spoken by all staff if your Spanish is limited. For the quality of food and service the price was very good value especially compared to somewhere like London.

review_preview: We found a lovely dining room. Simple, elegant, the perfect canvass for master painting. At this restaurant you will find perfect service and an excellent wine cellar. The maître is excellent at describing the menu and specials in both Spanish and English.We ordered the...
review_full: We found a lovely dining room. Simple, elegant, the perfect canvass for master painting. At this restaurant you will find perfect service and an excellent wine cellar. The maître is excellent at describing the menu and specials in both Spanish and English. We ordered the prawn croquettes, the scallops and the wild mushrooms to start. Each was better than the other and as good as any Michelin star restaurant we have visited. At this point we realized we were in for some serious dining! We followed with the Dover Sole en papillote, the pork rib. These might sound like old standards of a London club; solid staples. Wrong! These dishes were prepared with such expertise! A mix of perfect cooking, the right herbs and ethereal sauces resulting in unimaginable complexity! The food was so good it was hard to concentrate on our guests and the conversation.  A hidden gem at a very reasonable price! Well done Alabaster!

review_full: The service was fabulous from start to finish and we felt very welcomed. We didn’t have a reservation on a Tuesday evening at 8pm and walked in. We were asked if we mind seating in their basement and it was very very cute decorated in a Hawaiian forest theme. Adam our server was very friendly, welcoming and helpful with suggestions. The Winston Churchill cocktail (must order) was presented like a story and was very well mixed. The food was scrumptious - we ordered the tuna tataki, steak, chicken wings, and squid Bajo. Do not leave Madrid without visiting this cute little place. It was such an unexpected treasure. The other staff including the chefs behind the counter, bartender Evan, chini and Alex were all so friendly and pleasant.

review_preview: I dined here with my husband and 22-year-old son on a recent trip to Madrid.  We selected this restaurant because it was close to our hotel and had an excellent rating on TripAdvisor. We had a wonderful meal! Everything was delicious. For our starters, we...
review_full: I dined here with my husband and 22-year-old son on a recent trip to Madrid. We selected this restaurant because it was close to our hotel and had an excellent rating on TripAdvisor. We had a wonderful meal! Everything was delicious. For our starters, we shared sardines and scallops. I don't usually eat sardines, but these were large and quite tasty. My husband is a sardine enthusiast and was thrilled. Our entrees were also excellent -- I highly recommend the veal steak tartare. The waiter recommended a white Galician white, which was quite good and not expensive. In addition to the great food, I loved the atmosphere here. Excellent service and the kind of place where you can relax and enjoy the meal. Dress: (Since many TripAdvisor readers want to know) - Diners were nicely dressed. Business casual, business attire. Dresses/skirts/nice slacks for the ladies. I saw one diner in good jeans paired with nice shirt/jacket. Our bill was 164Euros for three people who shared 2 appetizers, a bottle of wine and a dessert with each of us having an entree and an after dinner drink. Not cheap, but a good value for a really nice meal. Highly recommend!

review_preview: Alabaster is resting on its laurels. The staff is attentive but take themselves too seriously. The food is nice, but not great. The cod chips and creme are interesting, but only for a couple of bites. The croquettes of mussels look great, but are too...
review_full: Alabaster is resting on its laurels. The staff is attentive but take themselves too seriously. The food is nice, but not great. The cod chips and creme are interesting, but only for a couple of bites. The croquettes of mussels look great, but are too soft and remind me more of mushy pumpkin nuggets versus anything that come from the sea. The sweetbreads were good, but the grains they were served with were distracting and took away the "sweet". The porcini & liver lasagna was delicate, but the mushrooms overpowered the dish and made it unbalanced - I wished they would have incorporated an acid to balance the fat. However, the sardine starters and the razors clams, with two different types of green fish roe and onion, were fantastic. The prawns with eggs were also good. They have a nice wine selection at decent prices. Everything is presented well, and they have a nice selection of dessert and well brewed coffee and espresso. I would take exception to earlier comments on the pistachio soufflé with ice creme - it tasted more of peanut butter and jelly with the bitter skins of pistachio than and any other pistachio dish (savory or sweet) that I have ever had. For the money, I found better value at the Spanish Farm or the sushi restaurant at Westin Palace.

title_review: If you don’t eat at this restaurant, you’ve committed a sin
review_preview: Came here with colleagues and we had a rooster dumpling in a broth as a starter that I think it is fair to say is worth committing a crime for. Larceny maybe. Or theft of under $100. Then came the grilled pork on a baked...
review_full: Came here with colleagues and we had a rooster dumpling in a broth as a starter that I think it is fair to say is worth committing a crime for. Larceny maybe. Or theft of under $100.  Then came the grilled pork on a baked mashed potato with spinach in a wine sauce. Oh my. Maybe one of the single best meals I have had in the last year. Tender doesn’t begin to describe the texture of the meat. Grossly insufficient of a compliment. Buttery and velvety would be a start. All topped off with a fresh crusty whole wheat bread to sop up the sauce. Foolishly I partook in dessert. Some kind of triple chocolate explosion that was creamy and delicate and, not unlike heroin, highly addictive. If there had been a second plate of that dessert on the table, I would have stabbed my boss’ hand with a rusty fork to prevent him from getting any of it. Oh and the wine was good too.  And of course the service was impeccable. Friendly, well informed, pleasant and attentive. Never had to ask to refill a single glass of water or wine.  If you’re within 100 km of Madrid you owe it to your tastebuds to eat here.

review_preview: Since I visited nearly a year ago and Rosi has received many excellent reviews since I thought I would sum up my feelings about it rather than be specific about food eaten etc.My partner, the kids and myself I arrived in Madrid for the...
review_full: Since I visited nearly a year ago and Rosi has received many excellent reviews since I thought I would sum up my feelings about it rather than be specific about food eaten etc. My partner, the kids and myself I arrived in Madrid for the first time in the heat of last summer and as is usual we stepped out for an explore not knowing where we would or could eat. We wandered towards Plaza Del Sol around lunchtime and an older gentleman gave us a flyer for Rosi La Loca which I took and we carried on. Upon inspection we realised that they were offering interesting things for lunch at a really good price so we marched back to Calle Cadiz. The staff were really nice, very welcoming, and we were given a nice table by the door amongst a lively mix of locals and tourists. Our food and drinks were served quickly and with a smile, and we left feeling that we'd found a gem.  If I'm honest I get quite anxious about restaurants when travelling; we've had our fair share of average/worse dining experiences over our years of travelling in Spain and I'm sure some of them have come from the fact that we're tourists with average language skills. So to find Rosi La Loca on our first ever stroll round Madrid made us feel like kings, and we remember it fondly. I should add that we enjoyed the Paella so much that we booked for dinner the next evening where we had the full sized version and it was glorious. Seating downstairs was a squeeze at times, but another lovely meal was had and we left happy once again. I saved that flyer as a reminder of the great food and that I must go there again. Picture attached.

title_review: One of the best in Madrid
review_preview: I have been here quite a few times already. The level is consistently  excellent, and they do try to innovate and bring new dishes as well.The place screams classy. Good decoration, ample tables, nice decoration, the atmosphere is well presented. Both Fran and Oscar,...
review_full: I have been here quite a few times already. The level is consistently excellent, and they do try to innovate and bring new dishes as well. The place screams classy. Good decoration, ample tables, nice decoration, the atmosphere is well presented. Both Fran and Oscar, the maitres, are both professional and warm. The personnel is very attentive, and they make sure that you feel right at home. Pleasantries aside, you probably are interested in the food, right? Your biggest regret will be not having a stomach big enough to order multiple dishes. They are very accommodating in terms of preparing half portions, so that you can try as many dishes as possible, however. The menu is consistently adapted, as I said, but they do keep plenty of classics around. The sardine is something you should not miss under any circumstances, as is the "merluza al pil pil", a fairly traditional spanish dish which reaches to-die-for levels. Seefood is a sure bet here in any case, scallops, "zamburiñas", "navajas", they are all reliably impressive. All the tartars I have tried here were a worth investment, as well For main dishes, I think their fish is the most remarkable part. They usually have some fishes out of the menu, and I would recommend to follow their advice here and try them. From the the meat, steak tartar is a favourite of mine, as is the "presa" (pork loin? I think. I'm not sure, many dishes do not have an easy translation to english). Desserts are not the strongest part, although I had an apple pie last time that made me quite happy. All in all, don't miss this one. The experience is pretty unforgetable.

review_full: This is a restaurant for a proper dinner. The local is well decorated with a modern minimalistic touches in white and grey. Fabric napkins as should be expected in a place like this. Glassware features a little bit chunky water glasses but excellent thin crystal cups for wine and spirits. Rest of tableware is ok. Appetizer on the house was exquisite and simple: fried cod skin with brandade. This marked the rest of the dinner for good. The scallops and the hand-cut steak tartar superb. For wines ask the sommelier, he knows better and has really interesting wines. The desserts are also worth a look... and a taste!

review_preview: Looking for a nice dining option close to our hotel in Puerta de Alcala, we tried first some expensive and overstated restaurants in Salamanca barrio but nothing really convinced us. Then we found Alabaster on TripAdvisor. That is a real gem !!We booked quite...
review_full: Looking for a nice dining option close to our hotel in Puerta de Alcala, we tried first some expensive and overstated restaurants in Salamanca barrio but nothing really convinced us.  Then we found Alabaster on TripAdvisor. That is a real gem !! We booked quite early for Spain 8.30pm but we have been very well welcomed.  From A to Z the service was great. 5 waiters for 12 tables makes is a very enjoyable experience.  Products are all fresh and the cuisine is from Galicia. We have been very well advised by our waiter and dine from seafood to shellfish and Atlantic fish. All very good.  For the wine, the sommelier recommended a local cépage from Galicia (Albariño) which an excellent pairing.  And for the finish we have been offered a glass of Moscatel with the dessert.  Chapeau ! We will come back.

review_preview: Just dined at Alabaster, and it was a superb dining experience! The chef's creativity, combined with the Sommelier's wine selections, were superlative!  The sea anemone risotto was an imaginative tour de force! The very knowledgeable and charming Sommelier paired it with a wonderful wine from...
review_full: Just dined at Alabaster, and it was a superb dining experience! The chef's creativity, combined with the Sommelier's wine selections, were superlative! The sea anemone risotto was an imaginative tour de force! The very knowledgeable and charming Sommelier paired it with a wonderful wine from Mallorca, Golos, that made the perfect combination! The lemon dessert--it is pie and ice cream and merengue, all in one, was paired with a wonderful St. Croix du Mont, just beside the Sauterne region and tasting remarkably similar! But also, don't miss the Chocolate Texture dessert! The staff was friendly, attentive, detail oriented and very hard working. Kudos to the Alabaster Team, its leadership and its energy! Next time I return to Madrid, I won't fail to come back! My only negative for the evening was the lighting, it can be a bit overpowering, with all the whites, greys and slate. So I would try to dim them, but if you're a foodie and wine connoisseur, don't miss this restaurant! Their lunch, even in the bar area, is equally good! It's true, I have no idea why this place doesn't have a star from Michelin, the team deserves it!
